talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Does the minister concede that the issue of the full sale of Telstra, as set out in the budget papers, contains significant elements of inherent fiscal risk? Isn't the full sale of Telstra completely dependent on assumptions on which the government has no guaranteed basis for proceeding, such as support from the National Party and a tick from the still undefined independent review? Doesn't the government's own charter of budget honesty require a comprehensive detailing of these fiscal risks in the budget papers? Where are they, Minister?

âContrary to opposition claims, the possible blocking of the Telstra sale bill has been included in the budget statement of risks. The budget clearly states in Budget Paper No. 1 at page 4-28 that revenue from the sale could be placed at risk if the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 does not pass parliament. The government is continuing to negotiate with the Senate to address their concerns with the draft sale legislation and we fully expect the bill to be passed. The full sale of Telstra was an explicit election commitment which was unequivocally affirmed by the people of Australia when they elected this government in October last year. Accordingly, its inclusion in the budget papers is entirely appropriate, and I call on the other side of the chamber to abandon its petty opposition to the full sale of Telstra.

answer.para: The sale of Telstra will give this country a chance to be debt free by the year 2002-03. No longer will the people of Australia be wearing the yoke of an outstanding debt which the opposition brought about. As those who are listening would know, a mortgage for an average man or woman can be a great disability, and that is how this debt is to this country. If we could clear that debt, we could do a lot more for the people of Australia but, unfortunately, the opposition does not see that.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't Tuesday night's budget debt reduction strategy completely dependent on the full sale of Telstra, despite last year's budget papers stating unequivocally that halving the ratio of Commonwealth general government debt to GDP by the turn of the century would be met in the absence of the further sale of Telstra? Doesn't this add further weight to the need for the government to be completely up-front about the risks facing this asset sales strategy? So where is the budget's comprehensive risk statement relating to the full sale of Telstra?

âI have already referred to the statement of risks contained in the budget and I would refer Senator Conroy to that section of the budget paper to which I referred. The fiscal risk to revenues and expenses associated with the Telstra sale, in the statement of risks, is recorded in a single description of the risks located under risks to expenses. The government cannot be clearer than that. This is after all the benefit of the accrual accounting system which we have brought into place for the first time in the history of this country. This was something that the opposition said was a good thing but they never got around to doing it.

âI ask my question of Senator Ian Macdonald, the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Minister, regional and rural areas have had some big wins from Tuesday's budget. Will you outline some of the benefits that will flow to country Australia from the budget, in line with the government's determination to maintain the balance between country and city?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe budget is definitely one for the bush. This is part of the goal of this government, because we wanted to make sure that the results from the Howard government's careful management of our economy and our nation flow to all Australians, including those in the bush. My colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald rightly identifies this goal in a very important question dealing with the budget's benefits for the bush. Senator Sandy Macdonald well knows of this: he is from the country himself. He understands what rural and regional Australians need and why they should share in the good times that have come with the Howard government.

answer.para: The thing that country Australians like most about this budget is its honesty. I might say that even the media have been surprised that this budget is one where the government actually delivers on its election promises. It is a truthful and honest budget, and it is financially responsible. People in rural and regional Australia, as Senator Sandy Macdonald well knows, get benefits from the fact that interest rates are kept low, that inflation stays low and that bush families are able to pay off their mortgages. It is a very responsible budget.

Bush people also enjoy the fact that the budget concentrates on providing basic services in education and health. More specifically, this budget for the bush makes services available to rural Australians and this means big things for rural families. We have provid ed some $42.8 million for 30 new regional health service centres. We have provided some $43.1 million for the rural GP retention scheme. We are providing some $8 million to enable a female GP to fly in and fly out to the bush. I would expect great rounds of congratulation from the female members of the opposition, but all of them are too interested in reading their papers to acknowledge this great thing for rural women.

That is why the National Farmers Federation, the Council of Remote Area Nurses and the National Rural Health Alliance have all been very complimentary of this budget. In addition to those benefits for the family, we are providing new Centrelink call centres in Maryborough and Port Augusta. We have provided, for regional Australians living in Tasmania, an additional $15 million for the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme, complying with and honouring the election commitment that we made. All I get from that senator from Tasmania is laughter. Labor have no interest in Tasmania or in the bush.

Yesterday, I was honoured to go to Tamworth to launch the government's $20 million scheme to help regional centres and cities with flood mitigation. We have provided some $7 million to extend the Rockhampton airport. We have actually honoured our election commitment, something that, after 13 years of Labor, rural people find a little surprising, because Labor never did that. We have introduced big, new schemes for local government, and that is why Queensland local governments have said that they compliment us on this budget. The Queensland Local Government Association says that we have got this right. That shows that the coalition are committed to rural and regional Australia, and there is more to come. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former South Australian Senator Baden Teague. I welcome him to the national capital and to the Senate chamber.
âHear, hear!

âMy question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Can the minister confirm that forward year expenditure projections were traditionally provided in the budget papers for all government functions and subfunctions? Can the minister also confirm that, on 26 April, the shadow minister for finance was provided with mock-ups of Budget Paper No. 1 which explicitly set out the same information on an accrual basis and that the shadow minister was explicitly advised by the minister's office that this forward year information would be provided in this year's budget papers? Can the minister therefore explain why none of this specific program information was included anywhere in the budget papers?

âThis arises, of course, from a claim by the member for Melbourne that key information contained in the mock-up of the new budget format was excluded from budget papers. This really highlights how desperate the opposition is in relation to attacking this budget. This budget provides the Australian people with the most transparent set of accounts ever produced by a federal government. The comments of the member for Melbourne are out of step with media commentators who have praised the government's move to an accrual budget, something which, as I said earlier, the opposition spoke about but never introduced. The budget papers, both Budget Paper No. 2 and all portfolio budget statements, provide details for the budget year and the forward estimates for every budget measure, both increases and decreases. There is no issue in this at all.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. There is a serious issue here, Minister: the non-disclosure of program information. So I ask you: does the absence of this specific program information from the budget papers explain why the Treasurer overruled Minister Fahey's decision to allow department of finance officials to brief the opposition during the budget lock-up on the accrual accounting consequences of the budget?
âRemember that you are representing finance here.

âI would remind Senator Faulkner that this is a finance matter and I am representing the minister for finance. In case he did not know, we have moved to an accrual based budget; we are looking at outcomes and we have moved to an outcomes presentation. Forward years down to output level were not included in portfolio budget statements but could be included in future years. There was a straightforward approach to the way this was handled. The shadow minister for finance, as with others, was in the lock-up. This form of accounting is a much better form than we had previously. The opposition wanted it but never got around to introducing it. Now that we have done it, they are trying to attack it.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Ellison. Will the minister inform the Senate how the coalition intends to honour the promises it made at the federal election in the area of education?

âAs we outlined in the run-up to the election last October, there were great things we had planned for the Australian people in relation to education. We have delivered in this budget not only by providing a surplus of $5.4 billion but also by way of a great social bonus in relation to education. Firstly, we have provided an additional $19.8 million for drug education, and that is something which all in this Senate chamber would agree is an important issue to address. Not only that, we have also provided $131 million in additional funding for numeracy and literacy. These are very important issues which have been recognised by all education ministers across this country. We have also continued funding of $90 million for Asian studies and languages, and that is a very important thing for the future of this country. We just cannot bring in these new initiatives and reforms and fund these programs without skilling our teachers to deal with them. What we have to do is provide professional assistance for our teachers, and we have put in $77.7 million for the professional development of teachers.
âWhat about the money for TAFE? Where is it?
âSenator Carr, if you want to ask a question, I suggest you put your name down on the list.

âI remind Senator Carr, who might not be interested in this, that this is a great step forward and it has been welcomed by the teaching profession in this country. But we have also provided increased funding of $93 million for the higher education research infrastructure. We have provided $25 million for university science lectureships. We have also brought about a fairer method of funding for the non-government schools sector. What we have provided is a choice for those low income parents in relation to which school they want to send their children to. So we have provided a fairer system of funding, based on the needs of parents rather than on the resources of schools. That is only good news for the non-government schools sector.

answer.para: Of course, the opposition has been party to much of this campaign, saying that we have neglected the government sector. Let me remind the Senate that, in relation to the government sector, we have committed an extra $1 billion for government schools for the period 1997-2001. By the year 2000 we will have spent 25 per cent more on government schools than Labor ever didâin fact, an increase of $382 million, more than Labor spent in its last term of office. These expenditures indicate that this government is totally committed to a strong government schools sector and a strong non-government schools sector. We are about parity and fairness in funding.

Also, we have before this parliament legislation which will provide increased revenue by way of the GST legislation, which will allow the states more money to fund those government schools. Senator Carr forgets that the majority of funding for government schools comes from the states. What we are doing is giving this country an opportunity whereby those states will have more revenue available to them, by way of the GST, to spend on things like education and government schools. These initiatives and programs are what we promised the people of Australia. We have delivered in full. This budget is an education budget which begins to tell the story for the next decade of promise for education in this country.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Can the Assistant Treasurer confirm that the impact of the GST has been taken into account in projections throughout Budget Paper No. 1, with the exception of the price effect? Is the Assistant Treasurer aware that table 3 on page 1-11 of Budget Paper No. 1 indicates that employment growth projections for the years 2000-03 are static at two per cent, even taking account of what the government calls the `job creating' GST? Don't the government's own budget papers prove that the GST will not stimulate employment and add weight to European Union experience that consumption taxes stifle employment?

âI thank Senator Sherry particularly for that question. Senator Sherry was part of a government in which unemployment rose to more than 11 per centâone million Australians were unemployed as a result of the recession that Mr Keating said we had to have, which was induced by the Labor Party. It always surprises me that Labor senators are prepared to rise to their feet and be reminded of the performance of their own government. In contrast to Labor, we have been able to bring unemployment right down. In our view it is still too high, and it is one of the big tasks which is before this government.

answer.para: Senator, I do not think you are reading your budget papers carefully enough. I draw your attention to a statement on page 3-21 of the budget paper, which I would like to share with the Senate because I think it is very significant:

In short, there is scope for the unemployment rate to fall significantly below its present level of around 7Â½ per cent (and hence for employment growth to outstrip labour force growth) over the medium term without igniting inflationary pressures.
This is the important thing.
Senator George Campbell interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator George Campbell was the leader of the metal trades union, whichâaccording to most estimates, and particularly Mr Keating's estimateâlost 100,000 jobs in his own industry as a result of his policy. He says, `Rhubarb, rhubarb, rhubarb.' That is what you were responsible for, Senator Campbell.

answer.para: Madam President, let me continue. Unfortunately, I am being provoked by Senator George Campbell. The budget paper says:
The extent of these further falls in unemployment depend, in part, on the extent of further labour market reform, taxation reform, social security reform and micro-economic reform more generally.

We say to the Labor Party: if you are concerned about the levels of employment, and if you are concerned about the proportion of people who are on the unemployment rolls, get out of the way of the reform process so we can achieve exactly what we set out in the budget paper and look towards the medium term and the longer term with confidence.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I think if Senator Kemp looked at the budget table on page 1-11, he would see that the government does assume that the GST will pass, and yet it assumes there will be no growth in employment even if a GST is passed. Does the government still maintain that no modelling has been undertaken by the government on the employment effects of the GST? If this is the case, how is it possible to provide these projections at page 1-11 with any degree of accuracy? Will the government now own up to the employment modelling it has undertaken on the effects of the GST?
âThere have been numerous models done on the effect of the GST.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are far too many opposition senators interjecting, and I regard the behaviour of a number of you as disorderly.
âOrder! When I am addressing the Senate on a matter of order, I do not expect senators to continue shouting.

âLet me quote one. The Melbourne Institute, using the ORANI model, indicated that indirect tax reform could lift GDP by around 3.8 per cent. Access said that the tax package could lift the GDP by some 2.5 per cent and create close to 200,000 jobs. There is overwhelming weight from the modelling that has been done on tax reform that it is good for jobs and good for the economy. Let us deliver our promises that we went to the Australian people with, and pass this tax reform package.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Why has the government failed to make job creation a priority of its budget, instead accepting that there will be no reduction in unemployment from 7.5 per cent over the coming yearâa figure that we have already reached, according to today's figures? Why has the government committed $111 million to the expansion of the Work for the Dole scheme, which its own figures reveal is far less successful in finding work for people than the labour market programs that the government scrapped upon coming to power, such as Job Clubs and Jobstart?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âUnfortunately, Senator Stott Despoja is very much onside with the Labor Party in this regard because she clearly accepts at face value Mr Beazley's tired and discredited proposition that many of those training programs and make-work programs, which were simply designed to entertain people while they were sitting on the sidelines, somehow have some current validity. Well, of course, they have not.

answer.para: We are very much concerned to reduce the level of unemployment, and I was pleased to see that employment actually rose again this month, with a higher participation rate and a marginal change in the unemployment level. But the fact is that the overwhelming impediment to job creation lies in those who oppose our ongoing tax reforms and our workplace relations reforms. I know you have no interest in the subject, Senator Stott Despoja. You think that being a celebrity, performing for the youth of Australia by getting your photo on the front page of magazines, is somehow the solution. It is not. If you are here wanting to play serious policy games, then for a moment try to dissociate yourself from Labor's rhetoric on these issues and concentrate on what it is that causes unemployment to be higher than it should be.

We have proposed a whole raft of reforms. You have consistently opposed the unfair dismissals legislation. Why? Because somehow you think there are a few brownie points there in appealing to the trade union movement. Just because the Labor Party are wholly owned subsidiaries, does not mean that you have to be. Why can you not face up to the fact that there are a lot of ways in which you can improve the labour market in Australia by giving it more flexibility?

talk.start.para: âSenator Alston, you should direct your remarks to the chair.
âI apologise.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThat breathtaking hypocrisy from Senator Faulkner almost takes my breath away but not quite. Youth unemployment is simply another classic example. Being opposed to youth wages, opposing Work for the Dole, opposing the Green Corps, wanting to reintroduce a $5 billion Working Nation program and wanting to bring back the CESâthese are all Labor Party policies. Is Senator Stott Despoja wanting to distance herself and dissociate herself from those? I hope she is. If she is, then she is on the same tram as us.

answer.para: We want to reduce unemployment, and the way to do it is to embrace the government's reforms. Do not expect anything from the Labor Party. You will have the opportunity to support some of these reforms in the not too distant future, and that will be the acid test. If you are serious about reducing unemployment, you will not have long to wait.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister seriously believe that providing a `one size fits all' scheme for 18- to 35-year-oldsâa scheme that does nothing for older workers and older job seekersâactually fulfils the government's promise to reduce unemployment levels? Does the minister actually support the idea of the government washing its hands of mature-age job seekers, providing no employment measures for them in the budget? Does the minister dispute the independent figures that show that the Work for the Dole program, with its success rate of 32 per cent, is nowhere near the 50 per cent success rate of Jobstart or even the 36 per cent success rate of something like Job Clubs, which cost only $1,700-odd per placement as opposed to $3,906 per placement? Does the minister dispute recent OECD Economic Outlook reports which suggest thatâ(Time expired)

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âOf course there is no `one size fits all' approach here. The tragedy is that Senator Stott Despoja, who seems to be wanting to establish herself with the youth of Australia, is not prepared to acknowledge that they actually do want Work for the Dole opportunities. This has been an overwhelming success. We are proposing to expand the number of Work for the Dole placesâdouble themâby the year 2000â
âIs that the best you can do, Minister? Work for the dole eligibility stops at 35 years of age.

âYou are just not interestedâthat is what you are saying. You are not interested in expanding programs that will actually give people on-the-job experience. That is what this is all about. This is a very successful program that is now being expanded in recognition of the fact that it is giving people opportunities. All you can do is carp at the margin and say, `Why is it neglecting the older generation?' In fact, we are extending it to 25- to 34-year-olds. So it is actually an improvement on the current situation. If you are asking, `Why don't we go even further?' then you are implicitly endorsing it. But you are not at all; you are simply utterly negative on the proposition. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Budget Projections

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Further to the question that was not answered by the Treasury yesterday and the questions from Senator Sherry that were not answered by the Assistant Treasurer today, I ask the Assistant Treasurer whether he can inform the Senate of the reason for the budget bottom line showing the supposed upside of the GST, such as increased revenue flows, but not including the likely downside, such as the extra inflation effect of at least 3.1 per cent. It may assist you, Minister, to actually look at page 1-11 of Budget Paper No. 1 to refresh your memory.

âHow curious it is to get a question on the GST from the Labor Party, given that they have now taken 40 hours to debate a very small proportion of the amendments which are going through the Senate but have indicated that, if the GST goes through, it will not be repealed by them. We had an absurd example this morning. The Leader of the Labor Party, Mr Kim Beazley, was asked in relation to the GST: if by chance there were an election and the GST were not proclaimedâand if by sheer luck they managed to fluke it back into officeâwould he proclaim the GST legislation? Do you know what he said?
âNo.

âNo, he did not say no, actually. The amazing thing is that he did not say no. He said, `It is hypothetical.' The point I am making is that the Labor Party is absolutely all over the place on the GST.

answer.para: In relation to the question that was asked by Senator Forshaw, let me make the point that we have adopted, as my colleague Senator Ellison said, world's best practice in delivering proper accounting in our budget statements. Very few governments around the world can claim to have such comprehensive, straightforward and honest budget papers as this government has, Senator Forshaw. Let me assure you that, in compiling the budget papers, we have followed world's best practice. We can hold our heads high. We have done brilliantly.

The Labor Party should recognise that when we came back into government, some four budgets ago, we were left with a disastrous messâa mess of awesome proportions. Mr Beazley was, of course, the finance minister. In four budgets we have got Australia back on track. We are now one of the powerhouses of this region. Our growth is higher than most other comparative countries and we have extremely low inflation. Let me assure Senator Forshaw that these budget papers are prepared according to world's best practice. We are very proud of them. I suggest it might assist you if you read them closely.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. The Treasurer might think it is amazing; we think it would be amazing if he ever answered a question. You might regard it as hypothetical; it is hypothetical as to whether you will ever answer a question. I will give you another chance. You did not address at all the issues raised in the question, which related to the impact of the GST in terms of inflation and why that was not included within the budget papers. Isn't this deliberate distortion of the effect of the GST on the budget more misleading and deceptive conduct from the Howard government and a likely breach of the charter of budget honesty?

âThe charter of budget honesty was an initiative of the Howard government that was opposed by the Labor Party. I am very glad that you asked me that question, Senator Forshaw, because it reminds me of a very famous quote by Senator Cook. In fact, I would say it was his second most famous quote. Senator Cook indicated to this chamber, before the 1996 election, that the budget was in surplus when there was a major deficit in that budget. If you are speaking about shonky figures and if you are speaking about people who twist the figures, look no closer than the neighbours that you have over there.

âMy question without notice is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the potential for a Senate reference to the High Court being required to determine whether Senator-elect Heather Hill has been validly elected. Has the government sought advice on this matter? If so, what are the details? Also, what action is being taken to resolve the issue before 9 August, when the newly elected Senate is due to sit? Will the government support my bill for a referendum to amend section 44 of the Constitution, which bans up to five million Australians from standing for parliament? If so, will it do so in time to have a referendum on that matter on 6 November?

âI thank the senator for his question. Section 44 of the Constitution has caused consternation in the community over a number of years. We can think of Phil Cleary and the Wood cases in recent years. I am aware that Senator Brown has a private member's bill before the Senate. I also recall that Senator Colston introduced a bill on the same subject in 1978, which lapsed in 1981. So it has a very long and difficult history.

answer.para: Subsections 44(i) and (iv) of the Constitution have been subject to criticism on the basis that they create confusion and unfairness in relation to the election of members of parliament. The Senate legal and constitutional affairs committee considered the matter in 1981 and it recommended change. The Constitutional Commission reported on it in 1988 and recommended changes. In 1997 a report on this matter of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs accepted the force of a good degree of the criticism that had been levelled at section 44.

The House committee, in its 1997 report, made 10 recommendations, including amendment of the Constitution to clarify and update the subsections and proposals to make intending candidates much more aware of the significance of the subsections. The committee was unanimous in finding that constitutional legislative change would be the only realistic way of overcoming the shortcomings that are perceived to be in subsections 44(i) and (iv). That reflects the bipartisan support for the change arising from earlier inquiries into section 44.

The government is generally supportive of the committee's recommendations, although further work will be necessary to get to the point of specific proposals for both constitutional and legislative amendment. It would be important to ensure that any proposal continued to attract bipartisan support. The government would be inclined to put a proposal to a referendum only if it had bipartisan support.

In relation to the Heather Hill matter, that is before the Court of Disputed Returns. I do not think it is appropriate to comment on that. A considered response to what is a difficult issue must await the decision of the courts, which are properly independent. You asked about advice. I will ask the Attorney-General if he has sought any advice on that matter and if he wants to comment on it. You asked what action we are taking to resolve the matter. It is before the courts; it is not for the government to intervene. You asked if the government would support your bill. We all have to wait every now and then to find out who will support what. You asked if it will be in time for 6 November. The government would ask you, Senator Brown, whether you will participate in debate to allow the passage of government bills in good and proper time.

talk.start.para: âThat was a bit snaky.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has outlined the long history and strong history of multipartisan support for a change to section 44. I ask the minister what it is that further has to be studied before we ensure that the rights of five million Australians are restored, in that they have a right to stand for parliament. Can the government give a commitment that it will move to allow the Australian public to vote on this matter to get over what is an incredibly outdated and unfair section of the Constitution which repeatedly brings trouble to the community?
âLet me commence by indicating that if you thought I was snaky in answering your question, I certainly did not mean to be snaky with you.

âMadam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Vanstone is copping the fault I had this morning. She has heard it from the wrong source. I made no such comment and would not make such a comment.
âI think it was from a Labor senator.

âAll I was going to do was assure you that I would not be snaky with you. I was simply indicating that we all would like our bills to be passed in appropriate time. All you do in your supplementary question is highlight that this is a longstanding problem. Governments of both persuasions have not been able to come to the point. If you were a member of a party that was ever likely to be in government, you would understand that there is a very long distance between a good idea in concept and putting it into legislative format. Of course, all good ideas have to compete with other good ideas in the legislative program. I have given you an answer. The government is generally supportive of those recommendations, but the government would want to have bipartisan support before it put it to a referendum.

âMy question is directed to Senator Kemp as the Assistant Treasurer. Will the government follow the Victorian Premier's lead in demanding that banks explain their `unconscionable' $10 billion, 22 per cent hike in fees and charges? Will the government take any action to address the Australian community's concern that banks are ripping them off, by, for example, instructing the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission to officially monitor bank fees and charges?

âWe, of course, are very pleased with the developments this government has made in financial markets. We have effectively made very dramatic changes to improve the competitive aspects of financial markets and at the same time provide wider choice to consumers. One of the things we are really proud of is the fact that we have been able to preside over a period where interest rates have dropped sharply. We can all recall home loan mortgage rates under the previous government. When we came to government they were over 10 per cent. Now mortgage rates have fallen to around six per cent and of course there are special deals which are available to people.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are far too many interjections on my left. Senators know that they are behaving in a disorderly fashion.

âOne of the things we have been able to do is to preside over this period. If you look at an individual family who, for example, may have a mortgage of some $100,000, this would save that family in the order of about $320 per month. It is a huge saving, which this government has been very proud to deliver.

answer.para: One of the reasons for encouraging greater transparency in financial markets is that banks and others have got to be more explicit with fees and to properly account for the actual cost of providing a service, so we have seen some changes in the way that banks and other financial institutions have set their fees. One of the ways we are seeking to continue this major reform process is to further increase the competitive aspects of financial markets. It is the consumer that is able to reap the rewards of these more competitive financial markets. We certainly believe overall, and from the example I have quoted, that the government's policies have delivered very substantial benefits to consumers of financial services. We, like anyone else, would oppose any attempt by any institution to attempt to exploit some market position by charging excessive fees. This government would always oppose that.

talk.start.para: âPoor old Jeffrey has got it wrong again, eh?

âI do not know whether Senator Ray was being sincere in his comments when he referred to `poor old Jeffrey'. I suspect he was not. Bank fees are informally monitored, which I might say your government did when you were in office.
âWhat are you going to do?
âLet me make it very clear what we are doing. We have carried out major financial reforms which are delivering more efficient services to consumers of financial services. (Time expired)

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I did ask you about what the government was going to do in relation to monitoring the bank fees and charges increase. I would like you to come back to that in the supplementary answer. I would also like to ask you: are you aware that Mr John Buttle, who is the Chairman of KPMG's Financial Services Industry Group, has revealed that the banksâthat is, the five big banksâare involved in a strategy:

question.para: . . . to drive out the less profitable customer by giving signals through fees and charges if their behaviour appears unprofitable for the bank.
Do you agree, Minister, that this sort of behaviour could be classed as unconscionable?

âMy question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Does the minister agree that economic growth is vital for tackling the legacy of Labor's unacceptably high unemployment levels but that more needs to be done? Will the minister inform the Senate of what further measures the government is proposing to generate real jobs? How will Australia's job seekers benefit from the initiatives announced in Tuesday's budget? Is the minister aware of any threats to the government's plan for improving the living standards of all Australians into the next century?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âSenator Chapman does raise very important issues because, clearly, ongoing taxation reform and workplace relations reform are critical to ensuring that we are able to expand job opportunities for all Australians. Today's employment figures are further evidence of a consolidation of the gains we have made to date in reducing the unemployment rate and maintaining a positive employment trend. Certainly the rise in employment in April was entirely due to a rise in part-time employment, partly offset by a fall in full-time employment, but employment has risen by over 400,000 since we came to office. So there is a lot that has already been achieved but there is a lot more that we would like to do.

answer.para: If there is one single thing that we would like to do, it is to get the tax package through the Senate as quickly as possible. Tax cuts worth $13 billion are clearly enormously beneficial to ordinary Australians, and certainly the $10 billion removal of imposts on businesses will put them in a fantastic position for job creation. So it is not just the expansion of the Work for the Dole initiatives that were canvassed earlier but also the commitment to 500,000 new apprenticeships and traineeshipsâgiven that they were run down by Labor to a 40-year lowâby allocating $1.6 billion over four years, and school funding continuing to increase: all these are very important and necessary measures.

That is why it is a great tragedy to find that on the other side of the house there is simply no interest in genuine policy reform. In fact, I was astounded to hear Senator Sherry get up during the course of the morningâhe made the AAP wire service with a headline `Opposition admits no formal tax policy'. The report said:

The Opposition admitted today it had no formal tax policy . . . Senator Sherry said, "I am certainly not privy to advance copies of any tax policies that don't exist at the present time. But it will existâour tax policy will be unveiled at the national conference next year."

Mr Beazley has told us, time and again, that there are not going to be too many changes made to the national platform, so we hold our breath while you play politics for the next nine months. That is basically what it is all about.

As Senator Kemp rightly pointed out, on AM this morning the Leader of the Opposition had a classic opportunity to explain what he would do if he were given the opportunity to prevent a GST being implemented. I think you could have heard the squelch throughout Parliament House; I certainly nearly choked on my mango yoghurt. We find the Leader of the Opposition simply saying that tax reform is not relevant, but what he has said previously is, `We'll oppose as effectively as we can, as people who know a bit about politics.' In other words, `We're world champions when it comes to politics. Forget that we've been done like a dinner at the last two elections, of course'âwhen he has been right up front driving the ship. Nonetheless here it is: so imbued in the Labor culture is he that he gets out there and boasts that they are good at politics, because that is what the game is about. So what does he say on AM this morning? He says:
. . . because we have one objective in the next few weeks and that is to defeat this tax and all our parliamentary manoeuvring is to that end.

So there you are, it is out in the open. There is no pretence that, `We are seriously examining the tax package,' and no suggestion that somehow, `We are interested in tax reform.' No, `Our only agenda is to manoeuvre to defeat the tax package'. In other words, it is politics, politics, politics: `We are not interested in reform of the system and are not really wanting to debate it, we are just patting ourselves on the back as great politicians.' More than half of their frontbench comes from the trade union movementâthat probably says it all. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Can the minister confirm that the new measure in the budget to reduce from $10,000 to $5,000 the amount retirees can gift to their children and grandchildren will cost some retirees up to $15 a fortnight in reduced pension payments? talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âIt all depends on their own performance and conduct. Nobody requires them to give regular payments of $10,000 a year to their needy children, but they are giving away more than the amount of the age pension each year under the current arrangements, and that is a nonsense. subdebateinfo.title: Public and Private Sector Debt: Budget 1999-2000

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Hill. Minister, is the government aware that if it was a business it would be described in financial terms as having a very low gearing, in other words, a low level of public debt? The problem is private debt, not public debt, isn't it? Is the minister aware that the United States, the United Kingdom and France hold the highest international credit ratings by Moody's and Standard and Poor's and yet Australia's public debt level is only one-third of those countries? Is the minister aware that a major reason for Australia's much lower credit rating is an appallingly low creation of private savings and a high level of current account deficit? Where are the measures in the latest budget to address these issuesâto address the current account deficit, to encourage a reduction in private sector debt, to encourage private savings, to encourage Australian venture capital formation and to encourage value added exports?
âThat's a reasonable question.

âYes, it is a reasonable question. We got half of it yesterday from the Leader of the Australian Democrats. In relation to public debt, I would have thought that the honourable senator would acknowledge that it is important to reduce public debt. We inherited $80 billion of debt from the last five budgets alone of the Labor Party and Australians have to pay for that. It does affect our capacity for sound economic management. It has the consequence of pushing interest rates upâthat was the Labor Party directionâand it put a lot of people out of work in this country.

answer.para: We have concentrated on addressing that problem. We are in a position where we are repaying public debt and we have run government surpluses for the last three years, and we are proud of it. Mr Beazley, as the finance minister, gave us $24 billion of debt in the last two years of Labor.
Senator Cook interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Cook, who is interjecting, was the one who said that the books were in the black when they were $10 billion in deficit. We do take that issue seriously.

answer.para: Senator Murray raises another important question which is relevant to the current account, and that is our capacity to finance our external account. And that is important. But a fundamental is that you have to have a profitable private sector with the capacity to save and invest in its own imports. We have concentrated on putting our private sector, and particularly our export industries, in a position where they can afford to pay the cost of the capital that is necessary, including imports. We have tackled those fundamentals. The way in which the Australian Democrats could help us most to achieve that goal would be to pass the GST. Why? Because there is no GST on exports. It means the export sector of our economy will be stronger, and it will then have greater capacity and flexibility to pay for the cost of its imports. Yes, domestic savings, private savings and government savings are important, and it is still a major challenge that is before us. But you cannot do everything in one day, and what we have achieved in reducing the deficit, putting it back into surplus and providing a fundamentally sound financial base for this country deserves great credit.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. The Democrats and I do acknowledge that public debt reduction has been useful, but the need is now to mount an attack on the current account deficit. Minister, could you outline in this supplementary answer what further measures you believe the budget has which would encourage a reduction in private sector debt and encourage private savings and Australian venture capital formation?

âI have said to the honourable senator that we have concentrated on the fundamentals. One of the problems under our predecessor government, the Labor Party, was that even when the export markets were booming we were running a huge current account deficit. Why were we doing that? It was because our own industry could not compete. They could not take the opportunities that were out there in the external market. Why couldn't they? Because they were suffering under exorbitant interest rates because of the incompetent domestic economic management of Senator Cook and his then colleagues. Senator Cook was a leading economic minister in the Labor Party, as much responsible for a million Australians being out of work and impossible interest rates for small business as any other member on the front bench of the Labor Party.

answer.para: Senator Murray, if we concentrate on building the capacity of our industry to compete internationally we will start to address the problem that you have identified.

Senator NEWMAN

âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
âOn Tuesday, Senator McKiernanâin a most charming fashionâasked me a question. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard âin just two days.

speech.para: Leave granted.
Senator VANSTONE: on Tuesday 11 May 1999 Senator McKiernan asked me a question, in my capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General, about jury service. The question was as follows:

Does the Government consider the obligation for a citizen to serve on a jury as a community service obligation? Has the Attorney-General's Department provided any advice to the Government, or ever been consulted, as to the probable impact of the removal of jury service as an allowable matter from industrial awards? What impact is the removal of leave from awards likely to have on people's willingness to undertake jury service?

Does the Government consider the obligation for a citizen to serve on a jury as a community service obligation? Has the Attorney-General's Department provided any advice to the Government, or ever been consulted, as to the probable impact of the removal of jury service as an allowable matter from industrial awards? What impact is the removal of leave from awards likely to have on people's willingness to undertake jury service?

In my reply at the time I indicated to Senator McKiernan that I would refer his question to both the Attorney-General and also the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business for their views.

I am advised by my colleague the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business that the removal of jury service from the list of allowable matters is part of an evolutionary process which was foreshadowed in the document More Jobs Better Pay, and which reflects the underpinning principles of the Workplace Relations Act.

Minister Reith advises that the award simplification process should continue so that awards are simple, flexible instruments that do not impede agreement making, workplace efficiency, organisational effec tiveness, or act as barriers to employment growth. Instead, awards should be focused on providing a genuine safety net of minimum wages and conditions for low paid and disadvantaged workers. Accordingly, it is not necessary to include in awards matters that are dealt with elsewhere in Legislation or are more appropriately dealt with at the workplace through agreements. Such matters do not form part of a minimum safety net.

Minister Reith also advises that jury service is not widespread in awards. Only about one quarter of all federal awards contain jury service provisions. In addition, all States and Territories provide some form of payment or compensation for jury service. Therefore, jury service is not part of a genuine minimum safety net of common conditions for low paid and disadvantaged workers.

My colleague the Attorney-General advises that the Attorney-General's Department was consulted as a matter of routine on a set of proposals which included the proposal to remove jury service as an allowable matter in industrial awards, but was not asked to provide advice on the probable impact of that proposal and did not do so. The maintenance of an adequate pool of jurors within each of the respective Australian jurisdictions and any related arrangements for remuneration or compensation of jurors are matters for the States and Territories.

talk.start.para: âOn 27 April, Senator Brown asked me a question, although not in charming terms. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an answer to his question.

speech.para: Leave granted.
On Tuesday, 27 April 1999 (Hansard page 3693) Senator Brown asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister and Leader of the Government in the Senate:

Will the issue of West Papua be raised in talks between the Prime Minister and President Habibie today? In particular, will the Prime Minister be raising the issue of recent massacres of people aspiring to independence for West Papua, otherwise called Irian Jaya? Will the government raise with Indonesia the bill now being rushed through the Indonesian parliament to separate West Papua into three provinces in the run-up to the June elections as a means of thwarting the independence movement? Finally, will Mr Howard be expressing his distress that mob intimidation can have an impact on the aspirations for independence in West Papua above and beyond the impact it quite obviously has on him in regard to cricket? Does the minister have any further information on my earlier question of him of some months ago regarding threatening and harassment of West Papuan leaders following a visit to meet President Habibie on 26 February in Jakarta? Can he tell the Senate whether or not it is true that the Commissioner for Police has now banned even discussions of those meetings with President Habibie? Are there West Papuan leaders still in gaol as a result of earlier demonstrations for independence, and does the government have any information as to the wellbeing of those previously gaoled independence leaders?
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard .

I did not raise the issue of Irian Jaya with President Habibie during my meeting with him in Bali on 27 April 1999. The meeting focused on developments in East Timor and Australia's concern that peace and security are restored there as quickly as possible.
The government has in the past, however, clearly and consistently conveyed to the Indonesian government its concerns over human rights violations in Indonesia, including in Irian Jaya.

The Foreign Minister, Mr Downer, raised his concerns about human rights in Irian Jaya with President Habibie, General Wiranto and Foreign Minister Alatas during his visit to Jakarta in July 1998. Mr Downer again raised the issue with Mr Alatas when they met at the APEC meeting in Kuala Lumpur in November 1998.

I am advised that the Australian embassy in Jakarta closely monitors human rights issues in East Timor, Aceh, Irian Jaya and other parts of Indonesia. The embassy makes every effort to follow up reports of human rights abuses. Embassy officers visit these regions regularly to monitor Australian projects and speak with local officials, NGOs and the armed forces.

The government has also been active in providing substantial assistance to Indonesian NGOs that are active in monitoring human rights and providing legal aid. The government announced in late 1998 the provision of an aid package worth $2 million to Indonesia's independent National Commission on Human Rights. The Commission has been a vital element in the creation of a more robust human rights machinery in Indonesia. Its reports on a variety of cases have been instrumental in raising awareness of the issues and putting pressure on the Indonesian government.

I am advised that the Australian embassy understands that the Irian Jaya police chief has issued an announcement which prohibited the activities of a group calling itself "Team 100" from publicising the results of the National Dialogue meeting between President Habibie and delegates from Irian Jaya. The embassy has been told that as a result of the announcement a number of command posts affiliated with the separatist movement have been closed. I am further advised that the embassy has no information on arrests made since the police chief's announcement.

The embassy understands that a number of Irianese are in detention in relation to their alleged involvement in separatist activities. Information from human rights organisations in Irian Jaya suggest that at least 48 persons are in detention arising from such activities in 1998.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âOn Tuesday, Senator Woodleyâalmost charminglyâasked me a question in relation to the Cubillo and Gunner cases. I have provided him with a copy and I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.

Madam Presidentâ on Tuesday, 11 May 1998 (Hansard page 4716) Senator Woodley asked me a question without notice about the costs of running the Commonwealth's case in relation to the current separated children litigation.

I now have a response for Senator Woodley and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard . Expenditure by the Commonwealth (both ATSIC and the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet) to date on the Cubillo and Gunner cases is in the vicinity of $6 million.

As I said on Tuesday, it is not unusual for governments to defend litigation against them, as the New South Wales Government is doing in a separated children case currently before the New South Wales courts.

The need for the Commonwealth Government to defend litigation on Aboriginal issues was one reason the Keating Government set up the predecessor to the Office of Indigenous Policy in 1993. In a statement in March 1993, when the office was established, Prime Minister Keating said:

"The office will also be able to provide advice and services to the minister when it would be inappropriate for the only source of advice to be ATSIC. For example where Aboriginal groups engage in litigation against the Commonwealth there may be a need for instructions to the Commonwealth's legal advisers of a kind which ATSIC would regard as inconsistent with its role."

From its inception, that Office has had a role of providing instructions on behalf of the government especially in cases where ATSIC has a conflict of interest. The Office acted on behalf of the previous Labor Government (and later this government) defending the Kruger and Bray separated children challenge to the validity of the relevant Northern Territory ordinance.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hutchins today, relating to bank fees.

The very important issue of bank charges and fees has been somewhat topical for the last week or so. We on this side of politics were hoping that we would have got a definitive answer from the Assistant Treasurer about what the government intends to do regarding burgeoning bank fees and, in fact, the way in which ordinary people out there are being stung every time they either go near a teller machine or a bank or have their salaries or pensions or whatever paid into bank accounts.

What we got was the following. We were told that he and the government were pleased with the present state of the financial markets. He went on to tell us there is a wider choice now than there has ever been before. He then told us that the percentages on mortgages have dropped. He then told us that the percentages on mortgages before were all our fault. He then told us that, if we are lucky, there is a special deal available with banks. He then told us that some families with an average mortgage are $300 a month better off, so presumablyâalthough he did not mention itâthey can afford to pay fees. He then told us there is more competition: he went around in circles. He then told us that they, the government, would do everything to make sure there is no rampant exploitation. Then somebody, by way of interjection, said, `Is Jeffrey wrong again?' The good senator avoided thatâin fact, he avoided the rest of it by sitting down.

The supplementary question asked, `Has your attention been drawn to this particular document?' Senator Kemp said, `No, it has not been.' He said that now that it had been, he would actually go away and read it. No where in his answer was there anything about bank fees.

Everyone out there in the community knows and understands that the banks right now are more profitable than they have ever been. Banks now, in Australia, are bringing in record profits. In fact, each year the banks are outdoing each other to bring in multi billions of dollars in profit. What we find now is that the fee structure of these banks is again in the multi billion dollar league. What used to be the banking system of 20 years ago when a small incremental amount was made on the percentage of loan funds and when there was a very low reliance on fees has turned around now to a situation where the banks are making it through both avenues.

We would have thought that the government would have an opinion on this, that they would have taken the question from Senator Hutchins and in fact said, `Senator, we are looking at this.' But what we found was that the Assistant Treasurer had not even looked at his mail on the topic, that they had been doing nothing about it, that they were silent about it. One can only presume that the government does not see this as an issue.

I must say to the Senate that it used to be the case, when one went into a bank, that one knew which side of the counter the thief was on. He used to have a gun and wear a mask. Today it is just as likely that it is the pretty teller on the other side who takes you for more than what the bloke with the gun and the mask used to years ago.

talk.start.para: âOr the man teller.

âOr the man teller that is there. I am corrected by Senator Crossinâquite correctlyâon that point. At the end of the day, this question of bank fees is something that will not go away. The ACCC really ought to be called in to have a serious look at this whole problem. It may well be that some senators opposite agree with Senator Kemp. Certainly, Jeffrey Kennett does not. (Time expired)

âIt is somewhat amusing and a little bit sad to hear a senator from the other side of the chamber making accusations about the charges that banks levy on customers and seeking to get the ACCC to have a look at them. It is sad because they did virtually nothing to improve competition. In fact, competition between banks declined during the sad, sorry, 13-year period of government that the Labor Party occupied the treasury bench. During that time, we saw a diminution of competition and a reduction in the competitive position of credit unions and building societies. Basically, the customer lost out.

speech.para: This government has said that the answer to getting better quality of customer service from banks and other deposit taking institutions is to see a massive increase in competition. In the short time that we have been in power, simple reforms such as the cheques bill have, for the first time in the history of Australia, allowed credit unions and other non-bank deposit taking institutions to issue cheques. For 13 years, Labor was lobbied by the credit unions which said, `For Pete's sake, let us have the power to issue cheques. Why do we have to go to banks to issue cheques?' I do not know why Labor did not do it, whether it was just inertia or maybe they were lazy.

We said to the credit unions, `Yes, we'll do that. We will let you compete head to head against the banks and issue cheques.' That was a very sound reform which basically put credit unions and building societies on the same footing as banks so that they could compete. It was put in place within the first 24 months of this government's legislative program.

Yesterday in this parliament, Senator Chapman introduced a report from the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. This government has led the reform agenda in the Corporations Law area. We are ensuring through the CLERP process that there is significant new competition for banks from a range of other institutions, including insurance companies and other financial institutions. Organisations such as AMP and other large insurance companies will be able to compete head to head for consumer banking. As the Treasurer has said on a number of occasions, when people talk about high charges or mortgage rates from banks, change banks. If you do not like what a bank is offering you as a customer, the great thing about Australia at the moment is that you can go to a whole range of different institutions.

Credit unions and building societies are offering more services in more towns and suburbs than ever before in the history of Australia. There is more choice for consumers in Australia than ever before. I have to tell all senators and citizens of Australia that, if you do not like what one of the big four banks is doing to you, go to one of the smaller ones. Tell the bank manager his fees are too high. They have so much flexibility now that they will offer you a different account. If you do not like what they offer you, go to another organisation; go to a credit union. They provide fantastic services these days. So do building societies. So do a whole range of other organisations such as Aussie Home Loans and RAMS. The competition is tremendous.

The sad thing about hearing senators from the other side complain about what the banks charge is that they seem to have forgotten, after less than a few years, what people received in their envelopes when they went out to their mailboxes during the time when Mr Beazley and Mr Keating ran the treasury bench. Australians have not forgotten the walk out to the letterbox when they got the envelope from their bank or building society, opened up their monthly mortgage account and saw the charges. The people opposite ran interest rates up to 17 per cent for home buyers and up to over 30 per cent for businesses. That is what people had to pay.

Let Australians never forget what Labor does to the cost of money from banks. They are the party of high interest rates. Through the history of Australia, real interest rates have always been higher under Labor governments and have always been lower under Liberal governments. Under the Liberal government when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister and Mr Howard was Treasurer, interest rates in real terms were much lower than they ever were under the Keating and Beazley administrations. When you talk about bank charges, do not forget about Laborâ(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to take note of Senator Kemp's answer today on bank fees and chargesâhis non-answer really because he spent the time available to him talking about interest rates, as Senator Ian Campbell has just done. The question to Senator Kemp was about bank fees and charges. Let us have a look at the situation of bank fees and charges in this country. Senator Kemp probably did not know the answer and does not want to know.

speech.para: In the last year, Australians have paid a record $10 billion in fees and charges to Australia's top five banks. We hear Senator Ian Campbell saying that if you do not like it, tell your bank manager that the fees are too high and go somewhere else. There are not a lot of other places to go if we are talking about the top five banks. The KPMG report released this week highlighted that the $10 billion was 22 per cent more than in the previous year. The five major banksâthe Commonwealth Bank, the National Bank, ANZ, Westpac and St. Georgeâhave all increased their fees and charges in the last 12 months. The biggest rises have been through transaction account fees, lending fees, credit cards, the use of ATM and EFTPOS charges. More and more Australians these days are using the facilities of ATM and EFTPOS.

The worst hit are the customers who can least afford itâpensioners and small account holders. Fees and charges are used by banks because they want customers out of their branches. They are using cheaper electronic banking. My colleague Senator Hutchins referred to Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett in his questionâperhaps this is one of the very few things that Kennett gets right. He said that he thought it was outrageous that banks have raised their fees so muchâthe Premier of Victoria making a very valid comment about increasing bank charges. He went on to say that he thought computer technology would have made banking much cheaper, not dearer.

What are some of the increases in fees that he might have been referring to? Let us look at them. The National Bank increased its minimum balance applicable to fee-free accounts from $500 to $1,000. That bank also introduced a charge for customers failing to pay the minimum monthly balance on credit cards within 30 days of the due date. The ANZ Bank has increased its monthly account keeping fees from $4 to $6. It introduced a $15 charge on lost cards and raised the current cost of stopping cheques from $7.50 to $15âso there is a 50 per cent hike in fees there. It has also introduced a $6 monthly fee on pensioner deeming accounts for balances below $500. Westpac raised its annual fee on selected credit cards from $18 to $24 and introduced a fee for overseas foreign currency purchases or cash advances by credit card. The Commonwealth Bank has also increased its over the counter withdrawals from $1.50 to $2 and increased its fee for cash withdrawal from ATMs from 45c to 60c.

The banks are using these fees in an attempt to force out the less profitable customers, but the highly profitable, of course, are provided with a waiver or reduced fees. Fees and charges now provide for almost 20 per cent of income to the major banksâand this is up 17.4 per cent from four years ago.

What is the federal government doing about this? In today's answer by Senator Kemp he could not talk to us about bank fees and charges; he could only talk to us about interest rates. He said that consumers were reaping the rewards. Of what? Of increased fees and bank charges? He said there were very substantial benefits to consumers. How? How can he prove that when he did not answer the question and in view of the facts that I have just read out about the evidence of an increase in bank fees and charges?

The federal government leap to the defence of banks. They are defending banks rather than the average Australian. As the Consumer Credit Legal Centre has said, `The government must take responsibility for the treatment of disadvantaged consumers in a deregulated banking market.' The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration has called for the Reserve Bank to look into fees and charges. Good idea. But it is not surprising that people have become increasingly disillusioned with the banking services of this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI was wondering why the Labor Party was bringing up this issue today and I had a look at the lights up there and saw it is a non-broadcast day. That is totally understandable, because they would not want the hypocrisy of what has just been said widely broadcast. If the public really want to have a look at this, they will have to delve into Hansard , won't they? I am sure Senator Hill was a little bemused by this, particularly when he remembers that under the Bannon government the South Australian bank lost $18 billion. That is the way in which the Labor Party looks after the depositors' money in that state. Senator Patterson would have been absolutely amazed when she realised that the Victorians, under Joan Kirner and John Cain, lost $12 billion of depositors' money. Here we have the Labor Party coming in as the advocates of great financial reform. Let us look at your record, Senators. The federal record of the ALP over 13 years is before us. And don't we remember it well. Anyone who was in business during the 1980s remembers exactly what happened to bank charges under your regime.
âWhat about increases in fees and charges last year?

âSenator, you have probably never been involved in a business in your life. I have. I was in business in the 1980s. Do you know what I used to calculate each year? I could write off 25 per cent of the money to the banks in interest and in charges. It was always a neat 25 per cent of the money. Under your regime, under bank charges, under interest rates forced up by your leader, Paul Keatingâ
âWhat about increases in fees and charges last year?
âThe last year of the Labor government? Is that what you are talking about?
âLast year.

âThe last year of the Labor government? Perhaps they did start to come down, but after 12 years of pain from what people had to suffer under your Labor regime. Let us contrast that with what is happening currently under this government. We have extremely low interest rates. You give me a choice between being a father and a businessman in the 1980s and being a father and businessman in the 1990s under this government, and I will tell you which decade I would rather be in, because I have seen an enormously low level of interest rates dropping all the time over the last three years because of the excellent economic conditions created by this government.
âWhat about increases in fees and charges? You don't care.

âWe have created those conditions, Senator. We have created not only a climate of low interest rates driven by low inflation but a climate of low interest rates driven by competition. The establishment of the ACCC and the entry into the markets of a number of competitive mortgage providers have now created a climate where, on interest rates, between savings payment and loan payment, banks have very small margins indeed. You are asking why charges do not come down. Charges will not come down substantially if margins are squeezed. You have to look at the ways in which the banks charge for particular services. Let us take Bankcard. You might say those rates are a bit high, but what a lot of people do with their Bankcard is put money on it during the month and pay it out at the end of the month. That is very smart, because they do not pay any interest, but the bank has to cover all the administration. That is why those charges do not come down. You have got to look at the scale of the banking system. You raised the report that came in from KPMG and talked about the $10 million profit.
âBillion.

âTen billion dollars. It sounds a lot of money, I agree. But, Senator, do you understand that that is only three per cent in turnoverâa very small proportion? Do you understand, Senator, that one-quarter of that $10 billion is actually earned in fees and charges offshore? In other words, we are making money offshore and it is coming in to help counter our balance of payments. I did not hear you mention that one, Senator. Do you realise that, because these are companies that pay tax, money comes back into the tax revenue that is used for the rest of Australia? All of that is a section of that $10 billion. So it is not quite as you say. This government has created a highly competitive banking system. Boy, when I look back at what we had in the 1980s under you and at what people now have in the 1990s under us, I know which regime I would prefer to be under and I know which regime the public would prefer to be under. (Time expired)

âI am a bit astounded by the response from the government today in relation to my question to Senator Kemp. I have just heard a great old apology for the banks by Senator Tierney. It would appear, on this anniversary of the dismissal of Jack Lang, that we still have their puppets and their spokesmen on the conservative side of politics. In fact, when Lang tried to do something about the banking system in this country, they intervened and dismissed him. It would appear that the apologists are still here and are still saying to us on this side of the house that we can trust the banks to operate in a community conscious way. I do not believe that they do.

speech.para: We now have five big banksâand I think back to when John Howard was the Treasurer and we had five big banks or four big banksâand we still have the same number of people controlling the economy. My question to Senator Kemp was simply this: what is the government going to do about monitoring these excessive increases in fees and charges? As Senators Quirke and Crossin have outlined, the situation isâas the KPMG report has identifiedâthat in fact the banks are trying now to drive customers out of their branches and force them over to electronic banking.

For a lot of people who probably were not brought up in the computer age, this is going to be some sort of major and traumatic change for them, when and if they have to go into electronic banking. A lot of older people, pensioners, people on fixed incomes and a lot of people who are members of the work force would have no idea what they will have to do to get onto electronic banking. A lot of these people oppose the idea of having to go onto cashless pay in the first place, but of course that was the idea of the time. That is what the banking community wanted, and that is what we have ended up with. I know that a lot of people do not like going through bloody banksâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Watch your language, please, Senator.

âSorry; having to go through banks to get their money. But we had to, because it has been worked out that way. And we do not like using any other forms of electronic banking or transfer. However, that is the system, and we are left with it.

speech.para: All my question sought from the government was whether the government will go and ask the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission to monitor these fees and charges and the rises in them. All I got back today was Senator Kemp saying that he would look into it and Senator Ian Campbell telling us what a wonderful system the banks have got operating now. What is going on is clearly unfair and untrue, and a lot of people who can ill afford to be affected by these excessive increases are going to be the ones who suffer.

I want the government to say what they are going to do about it. All we have heard is that the great idea of competition among the banks is going to resolve this issue. Well, I have not seen any evidence of that since, and I do not think there is going to be any in future.

talk.start.para: âI am sorry that the honourable senator, who thought this issue was so important, could not even actually stretch out his time. Had he actually had a look at the question that was asked in the House of Representatives on Tuesday by Ms Gerick, he would have seen the answer that Mr Hockey gave to exactly the same question. They must have had a dearth of questions on the other side in their questions committee today in the Senate, because they actually had to ask the same old questions that had been asked yesterday in the House of Representatives. That just shows you the depths that the opposition has come to: they cannot even dredge up new questions but have to go over old ground that has been hashed over the day before.

speech.para: To give a direct answer to the senator: Mr Costello answered a question on notice from Mr Kelvin Thomson and, if you had actually gone through and looked at those issues as well and had done some homework on the other side, you would have found that your question had been asked by Mr Kelvin Thomson. So it has been asked twice, and it gets asked again today. It has been answered twice, but I will go over it againâjust in case you cannot get to look at the Hansard and go through questions on notice and answers to questions on notice. Mr Costello's answer in part read:

. . . the government introduced into Parliament, on 10 December 1998, A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 that amends the Trade Practices Act 1974 to provide the ACCC with powers to monitor prices, in order to prevent the possibility of consumer exploitation and excessive profit taking in the transition to the new tax system.
In that process, it catches up the issue of bank charges as well, because the question on notice that Mr Kelvin Thomson put was in part this:
(3) Has the Government introduced formal monitoring of bank fees and charges; if not how will the Government prevent profiteering by banks.
The answer to that question was:

The Government will maintain its policy of informal monitoring of bank fees and charges. The major banks would voluntarily inform the ACCC of their movements in fees and charges. These arrangements would not preclude the ACCC from formally monitoring bank fees and charges, along with other prices in the economy, as provided for in the A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998.

So the measures are there. That is one of the answers. The other thing isâand Senator Tierney spoke on it quite clearlyâthat the KPMG report figure is made up of a number of factors for the $10 billion, and 25 per cent of the $10 billion in fees and charges comes from offshore from Australian exportsâwhich is really good news for Australia.
