So we need to look at that figure more clearly, and Senator Tierney has been over that point.

Senator Hutchins raised the issue of older people who have not been brought up in the electronic age. What did the Labor Party do about that? Not a single thing. But, as we undertook consultations right around Australia for the International Year of Older Persons, the issue that came up in those consultationsâand I was present at almost all of themâwas banking, banking, banking. So what did the coalition government do? Through the Business Partnership Program that the Prime Minister announced, it went to the Bankers Association and said, `We need a partnership to do something about that.' So, with the five peak bodies associated with older people, with the Australian Bankers Association and the federal government supplying finances through the Business Partnership Program, we set up a business partnership with banks to assist older people to use banking facilities, to train people in how to use ATM cards and to ensure that ATM machines are being located in places that are safe. They wanted to practise and teach them about that.

Labor complains, whinges, moans but did nothing for 13 years. We have in place, in partnership with the banks, a system that encourages and enables older people to learn how to use the banking system. It is no good complaining about it unless you are prepared to do something about it. Go back and look at Labor's record. I have here Mr Hockey's answer to a question on 24 November 1998. If you had read the Hansard, if you had listened to what was going on, if you had taken notice of what was going on in the other place you would know about that.
On 31 May 1995, Senator Cook was asked the following question without notice:

. . . what measures will the government take to ensure that the banks fulfil their community service obligations by reforming practices your government has been carping about for five years, inquiring into for five years and also doing nothing about for five years?
On 11 July 1995, the then Treasurer Ralph Willis put out the following press release:
The government agrees . . . on the need to supply better information to consumers so they can make the right choices about banking products . . .

Nothing was done. Nothing happened in August, September, October, November, December or January. When we got to 26 February, four days before the federal election, Ralph Willis put out another press release saying that Labor will monitor fees. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.2.para: Motion (by Senator Calvert)âby leaveâagreed to:

That the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate on 14 May 1999, from 10 a.m., to take evidence for the committee's inquiries into the Auditor-General's reports.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI table the statement and the report by the Director of Meteorology on the Bureau of Meteorology's forecasting and warning performance for the Sydney hailstorm of 14 April 1999. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ

Between 7.15 pm and 9.25 pm on 14 April a hailstorm of unprecedented magnitude for that time of year moved across the eastern suburbs of Sydney. The storm caused untold damage across a wide area. Measured in economic terms, it was one of our most damaging weather events ever Fortunately, the loss of life and injury counts were not as high as in other severe storms. Nevertheless the Government does appreciate that the storm has caused significant cost, distress and severe dislocation to many people which is very much regretted.

This was an unusual storm in many respects. Not in the 204 years of recorded meteorological history of Sydney has there been a hailstorm of such ferocity in April, and only a handful in the summer months have produced such large hail. Furthermore the storm approached Sydney from the south, moving in from the sea off Wollongong through the Royal National Park and over Bundeena, rather than taking the more usual eastwards path from the Blue Mountains to the coast.
The Bureau of Meteorology did not predict the intensity of the storm, nor did it issue a severe thunderstorm warning to the public.

The expert advice of the Director of the Bureau of Meteorology, Dr John Zillman, is that the professional judgments of the Forecasters that the storm would move off shore and abate were not unreasonable on the evidence before them. The climatological record and synoptic meteorological conditions did not suggest the combination of circumstances that would support a storm of such severity.

Dr Zillman believes that the technology available to the Bureau's officers was appropriate and functioned effectively. Similarly, the Director advises in his report that the staffing of shifts involved was adequate.

He has, however, noted in his report that the advanced radar systems becoming operational in Sydney is not available in other capitals. To this extent at least our systems are not as comprehensively technologically advanced as those available in the United Statesâa country which faces more severe weather events than face Australia's major population centres. The Bureau will engage an eminent US severe weather expert to examine our systems and make any recommendations for upgrading those systems appropriate to the risks faced by our major population centres.

While I accept the Director's advice that the staffing of the Sydney Regional Forecast Centre was appropriate, I have asked that the Auditor General extend the scope of the performance audit of the Bureau that he is currently carrying out to examine the allocation of resources against the management of known and likely severe weather risks in the Sydney region and more widely In particular, I have asked him to examine the policies in relation to the number and deployment of severe weather experts, as well as the practices in relation to the training of staff on new high technology equipment as it comes into service.
In addition, the Director of Meteorology will:
. accelerate an ongoing program of training its forecasters in new techniques for using radar to monitor severe thunderstorms.
. implement additional "silent" telephone lines between key operational centres to overcome difficulties caused by callers overloading the telephone system of their forecast offices.

. upgrade the radar data display capability of the Bureau's core regional systems and re-configure the communications between the operational radars in the Sydney basin and the Bureau's forecast offices in Sydney and at Mascot to ensure small delays in data reception at Mascot are overcome.

The Director of Meteorology will also commission a review by an expert in human factors management to evaluate the operational procedures and associated training adopted in its Sydney office, and more broadly. It is not sufficient that our forecasters have the best appropriate technology and professional training it is also necessary that the operational procedures and protocols that they are expected to follow are those that will ensure the best protection for the Australian public.

The intention of conducting these external evaluations is to ensure that in the future all Australian cities can benefit from the best scientifically sustainable standard of forecasting for severe thunderstorms appropriate to the risks faced.

Experience with the Sydney storm has also heightened appreciation of the critical interface between the Bureau and the media when intense and relatively short duration storms threaten life and property. Even if the storm had been forecast, it might not have been broadcast. I will ask the Bureau and the media, including the television media, to discuss arrangements through which real time advice of Bureau severe weather warnings can be given to viewers and listeners.

Madam President, this Government has increased the funding for the Bureau of Meteorology by $4.6m per annum over the past three years. This is a reversal of a trend of declining appropriations. We are proud of our weather service, which is recognised internationally as being of a high standard. Dr Zillman, the Director of Meteorology's, international eminence as a meteorologist has been recognised by his appointment as the President of the World Meteorological Organization. The steps that the Bureau is taking in response to this event should reassure the Australian public that those standards, hard won, will not be lowered, and will be improved under this Government.

That said, Madam President, the Director wisely cautions that severe storms are by their very nature difficult to predict, particularly when they occur, as they will from time to time, in apparently benign climatological and synoptic meteorological conditions. Regrettably, there is much still to be done in understanding the science of extreme weather events such as that which struck Sydney with such devastating force on 14 April.
I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the documents.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN SECURITY INTELLIGENCE ORGANIZATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebateinfo.title: Report of the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Committee

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator MacGibbon, I present an advisory report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Legislation Amendment Bill 1999. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to incorporate Senator MacGibbon's tabling statement in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
I am delighted to be tabling a report from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO entitled, An Advisory Report on the ASIO Legislation Amendment Bill 1999.
This report contains the results of our consideration of the ASIO Legislation Amendment Bill, which was referred to us by the Attorney-General on 13 April 1999.

While the short timeframe available to us limited the scope of our review, it is important to acknowledge the significance of the fact that the review occurred at all It is a rare event that the legislation giving effect to our national security and intelligence agency is exposed to public scrutiny.
In the report we express broad support for the purpose and form of the Bill.
We believe that the Bill generally achieves an appropriate balance between public and private interests:
. the public interest being to ensure that ASIO has access to the surveillance tools and techniques needed to safeguard Australia against security threats in the modern world; and
. the private interest being to ensure that ASIO's activities do not impinge unduly on individual rights and libertiesâprincipally, the right to privacy.

Nevertheless, we do believe the Bill can be improved upon. Accordingly, we have made a number of recommendations aimed at clarifying the intent of the Bill and further enhancing the accountability and reporting regimes surrounding ASIO.

One of the main issues raised in submissions was a concern that the Bill proposed to relax the test to be applied by the Attorney-General in considering whether to issue a search warrant to ASIO. We have recommended that a supplementary explanatory memorandum should be issued to make it clear that while the Bill rewords the test, it does not lessen the test.

A number of submissions also expressed concern about the provision, which allows ASIO to `add delete or alter' data stored on a computer. We have recommended that the Bill, and/or the explanatory memorandum, should be amended to make it clear that ASIO is not empowered to add, delete or alter data stored in a target computer, except for the purposes of gaining access to the computer.
In relation to accountability and reporting we have made three recommendations:
. first, that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security report annually on the frequency with which ASIO recovers listening and tracking devices outside normal warrant periods;

. second, that the memoranda of understanding regulating ASIO's access to tax and financial transaction reports (and any future modifications to these memoranda) be considered and cleared by the ASIO Committee before coming into effect; and

. third, that the frequency of ASIO's access to financial transaction reports information be disclosed in the annual reports from the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (known as AUSTRAC).

We also recognise the strength of the argument, put to us in submissions, that community confidence in ASIO and its operations would be enhanced if it were more open in its reporting of activities. While there are clearly competing tensions to be addressed, we have suggested to the Attorney that the nature and scope of ASIO's public reporting should be considered further, perhaps by way of reference to the ASIO Committee.
I believe that our review has been a valuable exercise and I look forward to the resumption of debate on the Bill and the Government's response to our recommendations.
On behalf of the Presiding Member of the Committee, Mr Jull, I would like to thank all the members of the Committee for their efforts in producing this unanimous report.
I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI take this opportunity to make some brief comments on this, and Senator Sandy Macdonald is going to follow. The Attorney-General referred the legislation to the ASIO committee for comment. Probably the only weakness in this process was the timing which the committee was given to bring in its report. One would have to say that, not by any deliberate intent on the part of the Attorney, the timing was very tight. It did enable the committee to fully cross-examine the various agencies concerned but did not give the various interested groups in the community sufficient time both to put in their refined submissions and to appear before the committees. Again, this was unfortunate, but it was in no way intentional. However, I think it would be appropriate if this legislation, when it comes before the Senate, were referred to the legislation committee to give those groups their one day on which to raise further comments on this bill and to give them an opportunity, through this process with more timing involved, to put their views.

speech.para: What is involved in this ASIO legislation is the classic example of trying to properly balance the security needs of this country with people's civil rights. In this case that is a formula that is extremely difficult to assess because, let us face it, ASIO's operation are basically covert. It is not easy for civil liberties groups or even this parliament to assess whether ASIO is getting the balance right. Nevertheless, all you can bring to bear on this is your own experiences. I am probably uniquely advantaged because I have been a member of the security committee for six years. I have been in charge of two of the five security apparatuses in this countryâDIO and DSDâand on various occasions I have had dealings with ONA, with ASIO and with ASIS. The security committee always took its duties extremely seriouslyâI am sure it is exactly the same with this governmentâand made sure its scrutiny of the activities of those agencies was at the highest possible level. What you need when you are dealing with security agencies is the right checks and balances.

There have been examples in Australia, but more often overseas, where these agencies have gone beyond their brief and have in fact been caught up in the internal dynamics of their own being, to the detriment of the country. I think ASIS and the Sheraton raid was one example of that. I stress that these are the aberrations; they are not the norm with regard to Australian security organisations. They are rare. Certainly, after the Hope royal commission and the Samuels report many of the problems of the past that may have been institutionalised have been eliminated.

I think these organisations have also become more balanced in their outlook. We are no longer dominated by the Cold War and the polarities that that developed in our society and what some people would see as entrenched biases in our security apparatus. I do not detect that they exist at all.

Over and above all that, we do have a major protective device on all the powers of these agencies in the Office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. This office is given the power to oversight the five agencies to make sure they are working within their legislative charter. I would have to say that governments, when appointing inspectors-general, have always done it on the basis of appointing someone of independence. This government has had the opportunity of appointing only one Inspector-General, and that is Mr Bill Blick, whom most of us involved in the Senate estimates committee process would recognise as a very capable public servant, a fairly fearless public servant and someone who will carry out his duties in this particular job without fear or favour. As such, that is the most reassuring thing we can tell the Australian public when we are looking at the checks and balances that exist.

There are basically three key issues in this legislation that will be of concern to people. Firstly, the access by ASIO to tax records and AUSTRAC records. This is something they have not had in the past, but I would certainly deem it something they need to use, albeit sparingly, in the course of their duties. With regard to tax, they do not have direct access to records under this legislation proposed. They will have to approach the Commissioner of Taxation, explain the purpose of their request and it will be up to the tax commissioner, under the powers in the tax act, as to whether he allows access to those records. The evidence given by Mr Richardson, the head of ASIO, was that he did not think he would need to do that on a regular basis. The access to AUSTRAC is also limited because they do not have direct, online access. They have to go Sydney, use a PIN number and access those records to assist themselves. So, in both cases, ASIO is not proposed to have unlimited access.

But I do notice this criticism around: why give ASIO this increased power? I look at it from the point of view of who already has this power. If the critics are right, they should be a lot more worried about other agencies having this power than ASIO, who have a fairly good track record when it comes to probity. You already have a couple of the more unsavoury, at times, state institutions like ICAC and the CJC that have direct access into AUSTRAC, and you have several other agencies with no better proven track recordsâfederal agenciesâwith access to tax records. So if indeed people want to argue that ASIO should not have this sort of access, they really should go back and look at all the other statutory abilities for other agencies to have access to these records which have a far less commendable track record than ASIO itself has.

The second major area of reform here is to do with the timing of warrants. It is not possible for ASIO to meet the same timing as to the issuing and ceasing of warrants as law enforcement agencies. Why? Because it is covert, and it is not always possible to get the timing right if you want to keep the covert aspect to it. But again the act, as proposed by Attorney-General Williams, does detail various restrictions on ASIO's ability to issue warrants. I think they have the balance right.

The third area that will cause some concern is the right of ASIO to go into computers to access information. Again, they have to do it in a covert way. I think the clause that has people most worried is the one that gives ASIO the right to alter information in order to continue the activity as a covert action. It does not have the right to just go in willy-nilly and change information. It only has the right to change a computer set-up to the extent to which they need covert entrance into it. Again, this is a modernising of the act. When the ASIO acts were first written, people did not think information to that extent would be kept on computers. We all know what has happened, even in the last 10 years, since the ASIO Act was last changed.

So, on the whole, I do not regard the legislation as getting out of balance the rights of the Australian community to expect a security apparatus to operate with full and sufficient powers as opposed to the balance required for civil liberties. One thing we should always remember: whatever value ASIO is to us now, it has to keep its residual capacity, its techniques and its abilities there for time of crisis. We hope that time of crisis never comes, but it must be in a position to respond to it.

I should say, finally, that the views I have expressed today are ones I have come to by listening to the witnesses and assessing the act myself. It does not bind my party; everyone should know that. This act will go through the normal Labor Party processes and, in turn, the Labor Party will either support or oppose it and, being a collectivist, I will abide by whichever decision they make. But I must say that, having examined the act with the other committee members, I think it has the balance right. I think the Attorney-General has drawn up an act that meets the modern requirements without being excessive, and I think that in terms of the civil liberties implications of it, the very defence of all this is the existence of a competent Inspector-General who will enforce the provisions with fairness and rigorousness.

talk.start.para: âFollowing Senator Ray's very balanced comments, I want to make some comments on this tabling of the advisory report on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Legislation Amendment Bill 1999. This legislation revolves around the necessity for ASIO's powers to be extended and varied to meet not only the technological change but also the times in which we live and, in one particular sense, the security requirements of the Olympics next year.

speech.para: As Senator Ray has said, we have had a short time frame for our review and some people who wished to have the opportunity to come before the committee and make submissions may have been excluded because of the time constraints. But, in general terms, the committee supports the purpose and form of the bill. The bill proposes to allow ASIO such access to tax and financial transaction report information as is relevant to the performance of security intelligence functions. We support this access, provided appropriate safeguards are in place. These safeguards are to be described in the memoranda of understanding being negotiated between the Director-General of ASIO, the Commissioner of Taxation and the Director of AUSTRAC. We think it is important that these memoranda not come into effect until after they have been considered and endorsed by the ASIO committee.

This is an important accountability measure. The bill proposes to extend the duration of search warrants from seven to 28 days and to allow the Attorney-General to delay the commencement of warrants. These provisions will allow a degree of flexibility in the execution of warrants that is appropriate for an agency that needs to execute warrants covertly. ASIO is not like a law enforcement agency that can execute search warrants in public.

The bill also proposes to allow ASIO to remotely access computers. This is an appropriate extension of ASIO's surveillance powers and enables ASIO to make use of available technologies. We have, however, made a recommendation to make plain that ASIO cannot `add, delete or alter' data stored in a computer except for the purposes of gaining access to that computer. This means that ASIO can unlock the door to information, so to speak, but it cannot tamper with that information.

We also support the extension of the time frames within which ASIO can recover listening and tracking devices. While we think it is far preferable that such devices are recovered within the period that they are active, we accept that it can be difficult to retrieve such devices covertly and within warrant periods. As an additional safeguard in this area, as Senator Ray has mentioned, we have recommended that ASIO's accountability watchdog, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, report annually on the frequency with which listening and tracking devices are recovered outside normal warrant periods.

Finally, it is worth saying that it is no easy task to achieve a balance between protecting national security interests and individual rights and liberties. We consider that this bill, as completed by our recommendation, strikes an appropriate balance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Jacinta Collins) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced:
A bill for an Act to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and the Corporations Law, in order to help protect the entitlements of employees.
Motion (by Senator Jacinta Collins) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

The Employment Security Bill 1999 that I present to the Senate today is identical to the Employment Security Bill 1998 that was introduced by Senator Mackay in May 1998 and debated during general business on 25 June 1998. An identical bill was also introduced into the House of Representatives in the last parliament and in the current parliament by Mr Bevis.

This bill was first introduced after Minister Reith advised the public that the government would put the issue of protection of employee entitlements on the agenda for the forthcoming meeting of the Labour Ministers Council in May of last year, but there has been no progress. Prime Minister Howard was reported as saying on 18 December last year that the government may review laws protecting workers and their entitlements when the employing company becomes insolvent, but this has not been done.

The Employment Security Bill 1999 will help protect the entitlements of employees by amending the Corporations Law and the Workplace Relations Act. It will protect the most important asset of all Australian workersâtheir jobâand provide increased job security. The bill is aimed specifically at corporate entities which seek to restructure and avoid their financial responsibilities to employees. More specifically, the bill addresses the circumstances of the corporate restructuring undertaken by Patrick last year when sacking its entire work force. The employees of the Patrick labour hire companies were left without their two most important rights. Those workers were left without any claim to accrued entitlements of annual and sick leave, redundancy payments and long service leave. These accrued entitlements could be made only against their direct employer, who was now a Patrick company in receivership.

Secondly, the workers had lost their right to be protected against unlawful termination. This right has effectively been rendered meaningless. Employees could be reinstated only to their direct employer, the Patrick employing companies. However, as those companies were in receivership, any reinstatement order would be of no practical effect.

Any employee of a corporation is potentially at risk of this type of corporate restructuring. Whilst workers have a legal right to accrued entitlements, there may not be any assets to provide for those entitlements on termination. Those employees have a right not to be sacked illegally, but a reinstatement order would effectively be unenforceable.

During the waterfront dispute last year, employer representatives did not condone the use of such artificial contrivances as a legitimate method of disposing of a work force. Speaking on SBS in April last year, Mark Paterson, Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, stated:
. . . if there are other sectors of the Australian economy unwilling to embrace reform, then this is a lesson for them.
Labor does not accept that employers have the right to artificially manipulate their corporate entity to avoid their legal obligations to their employees and, accordingly, is introducing this bill.

This bill will seek to remedy the insecurity employees face as a result of such corporate practices, which unfortunately at the current time seem to be extending from the small business sectorâwithin, as many of us would be aware, the textile, clothing and footwear sectorâinto much larger corporations. This type of artificial arrangement entered into expressly to avoid obligations to employees has no place in the decent and proper management of industrial relations in Australia. This is why it is even more concerning that it is growing into what we might regard as our more responsible corporate citizens. Regrettably, the current law allows it to occur. This bill will ensure that in circumstances where an associated company is able to meet the financial obligations of its bankrupt affiliate, it does so and the workers' entitlements to wages are met.

Obviously not every company placed in liquidation participates in the type of Patrick corporate restructuring. However, there have been many recent examples of employer insolvency which have resulted in substantial losses to employees. One example is the Austral Pacific company, where approximately 600 employees are owed $9.8 million in entitlements. The corporate structure of that group is such that the ability to trace ownership of corporate assets for the purpose of distribution to workers is complicated.

The government has tried to say that the circumstances of the Patrick corporate scam were unique, but this is plain wrong. Aside from government supportâor, as some have claimed, conspiracyâany corporate group could organise their structure so that their employees are employed by an internal labour hire company with a tenuous agreement to supply labour to the rest of the group. Indeed, many corporate groups, for quite legitimate reasons, already have separate companies within the group that employ the labour. Just as the separate companies own the assets, own the land, hold the debt or hold the tax losses, a corporate group could easily alter this structure so that they could do what Patrick's did.

The government has also tried to argue that other remedies apply under Corporations Law, but the amount of money lost by Australian workers through corporate insolvency today is staggering, and current remedies are obviously not accessible. Some other recent examples of employer insolvency and substantial loss of workers' entitlements are as follows. We are all aware of Cobar mineâ270 workers lost $6 million; Woodlawn mine, 160 workers lost $6 million; Grafton Abattoirs, 250 meatworkers lost $3 million; Rockhampton and Yeppoon, 157 hospital workers lost $1.4 million; Sizzler restaurants, 2,000 workers lost $2 million; and Roadmark, where $175,000 in severance payments is owed. This bill can protect those legal entitlements for Australian workers.

As I have said, the bill amends both the Workplace Relations Act and the Corporations Law. There will be two amendments to the Workplace Relations Act. Firstly, the bill introduces a new section 170JI. The effect of this section is to allow the court or commission, where it has made an order for reinstatement by an employer of an employee under section 170CH or 170CR and where satisfied that it is just to do so, to make an order with retrospective effect that a related body corporate shall be instead deemed to be the employer. At present, reinstatement can only be ordered against the direct employer.

Subsection 170JI(2) sets out the criteria to which the court or commission shall have regard in deciding whether the making of an order is just. These are: firstly, the extent to which reinstatement of the employee by the direct employer is impractical because the employer is in receivership or is in the course of being wound up; secondly, the extent to which the related company took part in the management of the direct employer; thirdly, the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the receivership or to the winding up of the direct employer are attributable to the actions of a related company; and, finally, any other relevant matters.

The proposed subsection 170JI(3) gives the court or commission the power to make orders regulating the contract of employment between the employee and the related body corporate and dealing with accrued entitlements and other matters necessary to give practical effect to the order. In the Patrick situation, this provision would have permitted the court to make an order reinstating the sacked employees to other companies in the Patrick group.

The various requirements would have been easily satisfied because, firstly, reinstatement to the Patrick labour hire companies would be impractical because those companies were in receivership. Clearly the Patrick group played a substantial part in the management of the Patrick employing companies and the circumstances which gave rise to the receivership of the Patrick employing companies were clearly attributable to the actions of the Patrick group. It was they who orchestrated the corporate scam which led to the companies being in receivership. The proposed subsection 170JI(4) provides a definition for `related body corporate'. These amendments will therefore ensure that companies cannot use the Patrick corporate scam to leave their workers without any effective remedy against unfair and unlawful termination.

Secondly, the bill introduces a new section 178A. The effect of this section is that a `related body corporate' can be held to be liable for the payment of legal entitlements to employees. The related company will be liable for the payment of any legal entitlements of unpaid employees in the following circumstances: firstly, a companyâthe related body corporateâhas entered into a contract for the carrying on of work for or on its behalf by a related company, the employer, including a contract or arrangement to hire labour from the employer; secondly, the employer has contracted to undertake work for or on behalf of the related body corporate, including the provision of labour services to the related body corporate; thirdly, employees of the employer are engaged in carrying out the work; fourthly, the work is carried out in connection with a business undertaking of the related body corporate; and, finally, the employees are, or at the time of the non-payment were, subject to an award, an order of the commission, a certified agreement or an Australian workplace agreement.

In the Patrick situation, this provision would make the Patrick group of companies liable for the accrued legal entitlements of the employees of the Patrick employing companies. These requirements would have been easily satisfied: the Patrick group and the Patrick employing companies entered into contracts for the hire of labour from those companies to the group; the work under the contracts was carried out in connection with the stevedoring undertaking of the group; and the employees were, at the time of non-payment, subject to an award and a certified agreement.

The proposed subsection 178A(2) provides that liability does not apply where the related body corporate has a written statement given by the employer. A statement for these purposes is a statement that all legal entitlements payable to relevant employees for work during the period specified in the statement have been paid. The proposed subsection (3) provides that the regulations may set out details with respect to the form of the written statement. Subsection (4) provides that written statements under the section must be kept by the related body corporate and the employer for at least six years. Penalties are provided in subsection (7). Subsection (6) provides for false statements.

Proposed subsection (5) provides that the related body corporate may withhold any payment due to the employer under a contract until the employer gives a written statement for any period up to the date of the statement. Any penalty for late payment under the contract does not apply to a payment withheld under this provision. Proposed subsection (8) provides that the provisions of the act relating to the recovery of amounts due under legislation, an award, an order, a certified agreement or an Australian workplace agreement apply to the recovery of legal entitlements payable under proposed new section 178A by a related body corporate.

To avoid any doubt, the proposed subsection (9) states that the proposed new section 178A extends to a contract if the employer is in receivership or in the process of being wound up, unless payments made under the contract are made to the receiver or liquidator specifically in respect to the legal entitlements of employees. Subsection (10) is a definition section.

The bill will also amend the Corporations Law in two particulars. Firstly, the bill inserts a new division 6A to deal with the liability of a related body corporate for debts of a company being wound up in insolvency. Proposed subsection (1) would enable the liquidator, a creditor or the ASC to apply to the court for an order that the related body corporate pay to the liquidator the whole or part of a debt of an insolvent company. The court may make such an order if it is just to do so.

The matters which the court will take into account in determining whether to make an order are the extent to which the related company took part in the management of an employer; the conduct of the related company towards the creditors of the company generally and to the creditor to which the debt or liability relatesâthat is, the employees; the extent to which the circumstances that gave rise to the winding up of the employer are attributable to the actions of the related company; and any other relevant matter.

Proposed subsection (4) provides that an order may not be made under these provisions if the only ground for making the order is that creditors of the company have relied on the fact that another company is or has been a related body corporate of the company. Again, this provision will give greater security to employees in relation to their accrued legal entitlements.

Secondly, the bill will amend section 1317HD, dealing with the recovery of profits and compensation for loss resulting from contravention of civil penalty provisions. Where a person contravenes such a provision in relation to a corporation, the corporation or creditor or the ASC may recover, as a debt due to the corporation, an amount equal to any profit made by that person or another person because of the contravention and an amount equal to any loss or damage suffered by the corporation as a result of the contravention.

These actions may be taken whether or not the person has been convicted of an offence in relation to the contravention and whether or not a civil penalty order has been made against the person in relation to the contraventionâproposed paragraphs (c) and (d). Proceedings under this section may only be commenced within six years after the contraventionâproposed subsection (2). In the Patrick case, these provisions would have meant that the employees of the Patrick companiesânot just the receiversâwould have had the right to sue Chris Corrigan and the other Patrick directors for debts arising from breaches by them of the Corporations Law.

This bill provides the opportunity for parliament to ensure that workers' entitlements are honoured and that artificial corporate contrivances do not deprive Australian workers of those rights. When this bill was first introduced, it was not supported by the coalition. Some coalition members felt that the bill raised issues of constitutional validity, amongst other matters. Constitutionality has been addressed within various pieces of recent legislation without disabling the government in addressing their concerns.

We would seek that the government senators act on concerns as expressed by the Prime Minister and by Minister Reith, and join constructively in supporting the passage of this legislation. We remain open to any proposals to resolve issues of concern with respect to the viability of any measures to protect the rights of workers affected by corporations using artificial contrivances to avoid their obligations. I know there have been many coalition members who have been concerned about such contrivances occurring in their seats.

At the moment, employment security is an issue that is of growing concern to Australian workers. Within the current context of the budget forecasting that unemployment will remain steady at 7.5 per cent well into the future, with reports such as today's from Ian Henderson that underemployment is disturb ingly high despite periods of steady jobs growth, with the department of employment forecasting a looming slowdown in jobs and given that the budget again did not offer a great deal in relation to assistance for the unemployed, we call on the government to honour the concerns that have been raised by the Prime Minister and by Minister Reith and to work constructively in this area.

Minister Reith has announced his next wave of labour market reform. Mr Costello reiterated yesterday the importance of this labour market reform. But this component is missing, despite the fact that the Prime Minister and Mr Reith have committed themselves to taking action. By supporting this private member's bill, the government has a means of being seen to be taking action in this area. I call on honourable senators to do so. I commend the bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âThe Senate is debating the Employment Security Bill 1999 yet again. This matter did come before the chamber last year and it did go before the House of Representatives last year before it came into the Senate. What we have here is an orphan bill that keeps wandering around the parliament, starting in the House of Representatives, coming back to the chamber here and then coming back yet again. I do not think there is a great deal of dispute from the government side on the basic idea behind it, because we do see, in cases where companies suddenly collapse and disappear, that workers can lose entitlements.
âWell, do something.

âYes, you have got to do something, Senator Collins, but you have got to do it within the bounds of constitutionality, and you did point to that towards the end. As I will point out a little further on in my contribution today, what you are proposing to do in your two amendments to two different acts of the parliament is, on our advice, actually not constitutional. This is basically the reason that the government does not support the bill as it is being put forward today. First, we do not think it is workable. Secondly, we do not think it is constitutional. The sentiment is right but we need to work further, and the ministerial council is indeed doing that. I think we might have to await the outcome of its deliberations.

speech.para: Before I get into the detail of the bill and the reason that the government is responding in a particular way, I want to put this whole debate in a broader context. It is part of ongoing labour market reform which was started about 20 years ago. The unfortunate thing about that reform process is that the last ALP government got their priorities all mixed up. If they were really interested in making Australia a highly competitive, world-class economy, they should have really moved into reforming labour markets first. That was the first priority. What the last government actually did was to start by reforming the financial markets. Then they moved on to the trading markets, particularly tariff reform. Then they moved on to what they called their micro-economic reform, including what they called labour market reform. Of course, that labour market reform was very much driven by the trade union movement, and that was their problem.

Because the Labor Party is a total captive of the trade unions, they had to respond to what the trade union agenda was right at the start. The proper sequence was to reform the labour market first to get the costs in this country down and make it a competitive economy; then reform the other markets and slowly reduce tariff protection when we have got industries that can compete and are not shackled by a whole range of uncompetitive labour market practices; and then reform the tax and financial structure. That is what they should have done through the 1980s and early 1990s. But, as I have indicated before, they did it the other way aroundâthey left labour market reform to last. They had the much heralded accord during that time which in theory was labour market reform, but it delivered to Australia a lose-lose outcome. What we had was the rigidities of the labour market retained but we also had reducing real wages during that time. What we have under this government is an opening up of the labour market and we are having greater flexibility in the labour market, particularly with Australian workplace agreements. Guess what is happening in this more flexible system? Real wages, when your income is adjusted for inflation, are actually going up. So we are moving into a successful policy.

In that sort of broad framework we have got to consider where we go next, and what Mrs Crosio first proposed and is now being proposed in this chamber today by Senator Collins is probably not the way to go. What we have got to remember is that what Senator Collins is driving here is very much the union agenda. The thing that amazes us all on this side of the parliament as we look at the other side is that we see people who were the head of their own particular national union or were party secretaries of their state division of the party. If you add up all the MPs on the other side who are in that position, it would be a huge proportion. Senator Collins is shaking her head there. I think she is indicating that it is not 100 per cent but maybe only 95 per cent. You are an exception, Senator Collins. That is terrific. You should encourage more people in like you, and then we will have a greater diversity of views and a greater contribution to the parliament. If you are not in that position, Senator Collins, I am really surprised that you are the one leading the debate.

The Labor Party has for many years been answering the call of the union movement on a whole range of issues, particularly this one. As we really try and reform the labour market, I must pay some tribute hereâI do not often do thisâto the Australian Democrats. They did actually sit down with Minister Reith and try to hammer out some sensible reforms in the first term of this government. Those reforms have been in place now for some time and they are actually moving the Australian economy along with a much more flexible labour market. The Democrats are to be commended for their cooperation on that particular reform. It is a great pity they are not quite as cooperative on tax reform at this stage. But we do not expect cooperation from the Labor Party on this because we know they are just the servants of the union movement.

What they are trying to do, of course, is wind back the industrial relations clock to bring in things like secondary boycotts and strike pay. They do not lose their old agenda. They want to abolish youth wages. There is a sunset clause on that particular labour market reform and, if that comes into effect, next year we are going to have a huge increase in youth unemployment because that reform will disappear under a sunset provision. So, even though they say they stand up for the workers, they are always arguing very strongly in this place for those who are in the employed work force, trying to do things for their conditions and resisting the types of reform that are very much needed.

We have some allies in the views I am expressing here about the role of the trade union movement in this sort of reform. People like Mark Latham from the ALP, for example, lament that the union movement already exercises tremendous power in the ALP, mainly through its support for the ruling faction in each state branch.

Simon Crean really wants to turn the clock back on labour market reform. This is a man who, when Mr Beazley falls over, as he inevitably will soon, will probably be the next Labor leader. He is a former ACTU president. The Labor Party would be totally back in the grip of the union movement if we go to Simon Crean. His policy is back to the future, back to the eighties: revive the accord and once again give the union movement a seat at the cabinet tableâif Labor were fortunate enough to be re-elected to governmentâand of course then bring back secondary boycotts and reintroduce strike pay. That is the agenda of the Labor Party and what they are trying to do here today, in a very unrealistic way, is move their agenda further on.

Why are they so interested in this particular aspect of labour market reform? You have to look back to the waterfront strikes of last year to find the real answer to that and to the groundbreaking work by Minister Reith. I think he will go down in history as a hero of labour market reform because he is the first minister who has really achieved any meaningful gains in a very frustrating area of reform in this country. It has been an issue which I have followed every since I have been in the parliament, and I watched with great interest what Minister Reith did last year.

Some substantial reforms have come out of that, a far cry from what was happening when I first came into this parliament. We then had Minister Collinsânot Senator Jacinta Collins but Minister Bob Collinsâwho was the minister for the waterfront. When I came into this parliament in 1991, he had said the previous year, `If I don't reform the waterfront with labour market reforms in one year, I will resign.' When I came in, it was 71 days to resignation day and we continued the countdown.

Senators who were here at the time, like Senator O'Chee, will remember that countdown. We would say, `Well, 70 days to go.' He instituted a number of very minor reforms and the main outcome of them was that the Commonwealth government spent another $450 million in paying out redundant workers, a lot of whom actually came back later as casual employees. They took their redundancy pay, pocketed that, then rejoined the work force casually and came back and made a lot more money. So that was Labor's approach under the WIRA agreements, which was not particularly useful.

We had to wait for Peter Reith to come in and make a number of very courageous decisions in conjunction with Patricks, who really put their head on the chopping block in the way in which they expressed the reforms and went ahead with those reforms. I can understand why they did it. They had come and seen our committeeânot just them, but a group of stevedoresâand they were totally frustrated with being ripped off by unfair work practices on the waterfront. We got to that point last year and they put forward a range of reforms that are making this country a lot more competitive.

From that situation we come to this particular bill today because what was proposed and what came out of the Patricks case was a need to protect people who had lost their jobs suddenly. There is considerable concern across the community on that issue and the government does acknowledge that and would like to move to improve the situation. But broadly we would like to point out that there is a whole range of provisions in law at the moment, under the two acts that I will mention in a moment, that put those protections in at this time, and this bill is miscast in a number of ways because of that. It is also miscast, as I indicated earlier, because it is a bill which has doubtful constitutional validity in the way in which it approaches a certain number of matters, and I will mention those in a moment.

The remedies in the Employment Security Bill that we are debating today deal with the Corporations Law and the Workplace Relations Act. In terms of the Workplace Relations Act, it proposes to empower the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or the Federal Court to order that a body corporate relating to the employer be deemed to be the employer for the purpose of a reinstatement order. It also makes a related body corporate liable for the payment of the legal entitlements of employees of an insolvent company.

The second thing it proposes to do, through the Corporations Law, is enable a liquidator or a creditor or the ASIC to apply to the Federal Court for an order that the related body corporate pay the liquidator for the whole, or part of the, debt of an insolvent company. It also proposes allowing a creditor or the ASIC to seek a recovery when loss or damages have been suffered as a result of a breach by a director or another officer.

The problem with what they are proposing is that it substantially duplicates recommendations already made in the 1988 report by the general insolvency inquiry, known as the Harmer report. Those recommendations were not adopted into law by the then Labor government so the first thing Senator Collins should do is go back, have a look at the Harmer report and actually realise, in terms of the constitutional validity of the law, why that actually was not done.

The amendments that are put forward in this bill are based on outdated provisions of the Corporations Law. The Treasury has advised that the Corporations Law changes proposed are either redundant or unworkable so, if that is the case, why on earth would the government support this bill that is before the parliament? We do not want provisions that are redundant; we certainly want provisions that are workable and that is not the case in this. So we have a bill that does not add anything but it does duplicate and it does create considerable confusion.

If we take, for example, the area relating to directors who do not owe a duty to the creditors, it is a fundamental nature of collective insolvency proceedings that such actions are only available to the liquidator or with the liquidator's provisions. The liquidator is charged with managing the prospective actions of the company on behalf of all creditors. His role could be seriously compromised if individual creditors were permitted to bring action at will, and that is what is proposed by the Labor Party's changes.

The amendments that Senator Collins is proposing under this bill do nothing to address the situation where several creditors bring action over a single alleged wrong. The law already contains extensive provision for the recovery and return of moneys to insolvent companies for the benefit of all creditors. Liquidators and unsecured creditors can sue a director directly for compensation for loss or damage suffered as a result of a company trading when insolvent. There are also provisions which allow a reversal by a liquidator of transactions which lead to insolvency.

If the intention behind the proposal is to expose the acts of directors to actions of creditors, even in a financially healthy company this would amount to a fundamental change to corporate law and policy which would have a very serious ramification on the way companies conduct their business. Creditors have no interest in the conduct of directors except to the extent they impact on the ability of companies to pay their debts. Even shareholders do not have the same rights as proposed here. The Australian Government Solicitor has advised that the bill as drafted would probably be invalid; however, the broad intentions could probably be implemented by Commonwealth legislation that would be within constitutional restraints.

Finally, I suggest to Senator Collins and Mrs Crosio, who originally proposed this bill, that the government is opposing it not because we do not agree with the underlying sentiment, but because the bill is basically miscast, it will not achieve the objectives that are set out and it will probably be found in a court of law to not have constitutional validity. On that basis the government opposes this legislation.

talk.start.para: âI do not intend to speak at length on this bill, but I do want to recap a little bit of history. This issue is not a new one. Hearing some of the contributions to date, it may be thought that it really dates from the circumstances surrounding the Patricks, Cobar and Woodlawn issues.
âIt goes back further than that.

âThat is right. Senator George Campbell, who has great experience in these matters, says that it goes back a lot further than that. That is the point I want to make. In 1988 the Labor government referred this matter to the Law Reform Commission, which brought down some recommendations as to how the matter could be addressed and fixed. The Labor government in its next seven years of government failed to fix the problem. That is a great shame, because the consequence of failing to address the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission meant that the workers affected in Cobar, Woodlawn, Patricks and many other instances lost their entitlements.

speech.para: The next stage was when events did come to a head about the Patricks time. At that time, on behalf of the Australian Democrats I went back to the Law Reform Commission's recommendations, had an amendment designed to address most of this problem and put that amendment to the Corporations Law bill, which was before the Senate at the time. Labor supported the amendment, as did the two Greens and the two Independents. The consequence of that was that it went down to the House of Representatives for approval. The government, with its numbers down there, rejected it and when it came back up here Labor failed to insist on that amendment. The result is that, a year later, we are still left without the protection that you are now addressing.

There is a failure of will there, frankly, which dates back to 1988. I am very pleased to see that the honourable member Crosio from the House of Representatives and Senator Jacinta Collins from the Senate have decided to address this matter now.

In this contribution I do not wish to deal with any of the possible defects that may be within the bill. Defects can always be amended and improved. I recognise that the bill has echoes of the various amendments and recommendations of the Law Reform Commission of so long ago, but I would not like to see this languishing in the bill limbo land which private members' bills do have in the Senate. I say to the Labor Party: from 1 July when we combine we will have the numbers in the Senate and, if you want us to support you in having this bill debated cognately with any workplace relations bill or Corporations Law bill that is before the Senate, I would be prepared to support that and go to my party room to argue that we support it. This is a serious issue that needs to be raised as such.

Having said that, I say this to the government: if you do have problems with the way the bill is expressed at present and if you do have genuine concerns, you heard the offer from Senator Collins and you had better come up with your own solution to a problem which you yourselves have recognised and get the Labor Party to agree to it and get it done. Otherwise you are going to be faced with the situation where the combination of the Labor Party and the Democrats will address this problem because it must be addressed. It is not fair or right that ordinary workers, ordinary employees, should be put at risk and lose their entitlements in the manner they have.

The fact is, the government, the ministers, the Prime Minister and the coalition members and senators recognise there is a problem. Our party, for one, would be delighted if the official opposition and the government got together and fixed itâand fixed it soon.

Having said that, I should also indicate that this problem of restructuring companies to avoid obligations to employees does not affect just employees. It is quite possible for corporations to restructure themselves to avoid their obligations to other creditorsâsuppliers, landlords and anyone with whom they have a contractual relationship.

That is what it is about. At the heart of this bill is a discussion on contract, on the way in which devious corporations can manipulate the law to avoid their obligations under contract. In this case the emphasis of Senator Collins is on contracts with employees, but it also can be, as I said, on contracts with any other form of supplier, be it landlords or normal suppliers, normal creditors and those sorts of people.

In concluding my short remarks, I am sure that this billâas any other billâcould be improved. We certainly will work with the Labor Party to get an improved bill into law, and we will have the numbers with them to make sure that this matter is put on the agenda and does not languish as private members' bills normally do. If the government has that knowledge in their heads, hopefully they will take the bill seriously and do something to address this problem.

talk.start.para: âI take note of the offer made by Senator Murray on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We may well call on them in the not too distant future.

speech.para: I commence my remarks by making a brief reference to a point raised by Senator Murray and the recommendations of the Law Commission in 1988. While I acknowledge that those recommendations were not given effect to by the Labor government over the period from 1988 to 1996, I doubt very much if those recommendations in themselves would have addressed the sorts of issues that we were confronted with in the Patricks dispute, or Woodlawn mines, or Ashanti. No-one contemplated the company restructuring that occurred to create the hollow logs in order to avoid the obligations that companies have in respect of their employees. It has given a whole new meaning to the issues that we are trying to address. I think it is a bit hypocritical of Senator Tierney, the first government speaker, to berate us for endeavouring to try to address an issue that essentially arose from an agenda that this government was very much at the heart of.

Senator Tierney said that the government would like to move to improve the situation, but then went on to say, `Butâbut, but, butâthere are all these reasons why we cannot do it.' There is no reason why they cannot do it. If there is a constitutional problem, then let them come and work with the opposition in resolving that. We can accommodate a meeting to overcome the constitutional problems if they are the concerns the government have. If there are other issues in relation to the bill that they see are problems, then they can come along and work with us and we will work it through, provided that at the end of the day we put something in law that genuinely is about protecting the earnings of ordinary battlers, because that is what is at stake here. In many respects, it is the deferred earnings of workers that are being ripped off as a result of these malpractices that have been occurring with company insolvencies.

I say that because I think the role of the Howard government has to be assessed in the context not of their rhetoric but of their actions. Before the 1996 election they said they were about a fair go for all Australians. They continued to say that they had the interests of the battlers at heart, that they were the true representatives of the battlers in this country. If they were really interested in defending the rights of battlers, they would have done something fairly quickly to address this issue when it became apparent.

Let us have a look at where the issue actually emerged. Where did the hollow log strategy actually emerge? It emerged from the Patricks dispute. It emerged from the dispute on the Australian waterfront and the reform agenda that this government was pursuing in terms of the waterfront in conjunction and in collusion with Patricks Stevedores. And no-one can suggest to meâgiven all that we know about that dispute; given the amount of money this government poured into consultancies, advisers and providing assistance to the companies in that disputeâthat they were not aware at any time through that process that what Patricks was doing was creating hollow log companies in order to shift the employment of their employees to avoid any liabilities in the result that the dispute went their way.

The government had to know. The minister for workplace relations had to know that Patricks was contemplating this action. They seemed to know pretty much everything else that was going on around the waterfront at the time. It is interesting, isn't it, that within three hours of Patricks making an announcement at 8 o'clock in the evening that they were going to sack all their employees, this government responded with an announcement that they were going to introduce legislation the next morning in the parliament to set up a $250 million fund in order to pay out the redundancy money on the waterfront.

Now you would not argue that there was not collusion in that environment. Was it just accidental that the draftsman happened to have that sort of bill sitting ready in the eventuality that something might happen on the waterfront? When there is that degree of relationship between the events on the waterfront, then you have to draw the conclusion that the government knew what Patricks was intending to do with the hollow log strategy. And obviously, that was the case on the waterfront. What did that do? That sent a very clear message to every other employer in the country that they ought to be doing the same thingâ`If you have a problem with your work force, if you want to get rid of your work force, if you want to make people redundant, here is the strategy in order to avoid any financial obligations to that work force. Here is the way to do it.'

You could hardly blame employers, most of whom are greedy anyway, of taking advantage of a set of circumstances that is being presented to them. A number of them did. What was the cost of that to ordinary workers?

I want to run through some of the companies. Woodlawn mine: 160 workers lost $6 million in deferred income. Cobar mine: workers lost $5.4 million in retrenchment pay that remains outstanding, despite the fact that the parent company, Ashanti, after Cobar mine closed down, managed to pay its shareholders a dividend of 20c a share totalling over $US21 million. It could not pay $5.4 million to its employees. It had ripped off its employees' deferred earnings, but was able to pay a dividend of 20 per cent to its shareholders shortly after that occasion. Austral Pacific Bus Company: 700 workers lost almost $10 million of income that disappeared into a hollow log. Grafton Abattoir: 250 workers lost $3 million of their deferred income, again, into a hollow log.

In most if not all of these cases the employees believed that the employer they signed up with for employment when they first joined the company was the employer that was actually employing them. In most of those cases, there had been a shift in the corporate structure of the company which had changed that employer-employee relationship and for no reason other than simply avoiding any liability in respect of the income of those employees. It was interesting and enlightening to hear the comments of one of the miners at Cobar mine on the Lateline program on 24 March 1998, Mr Tony Chaplain, who had this to say about his predicament:

I don't want my sons down the track to be in the same position I'm in here, of losing everything they've worked for, of nine years of their life, or in the case of my father, 25 years of his life. If the laws aren't changed, the mine can start up in Cobar in six months' time and we could be in the same position we are six months after that. This whole issue has to be dealt with now. And if the Prime Minister thinks it's not a major decision, well, he's damn wrong.

We need a strong mechanism outside of companies in order to protect employees' entitlements. If there has been any experience over the past couple of years, that is fundamentally clear to everyone. The current provisions of the law do not act to adequately protect employees' entitlements. The nature and the way in which companies are now functioning in treating this matter of itself has created the imperative for legislation to be introduced in order to ensure that there is a measure of protection for workers and to avoid the sorts of examples which I have just outlined from occurring again.

The Employment Security Bill 1999 , which has been proposed by Senator Collins, is an attempt to create an insurance scheme that will protect workers' wages. At the end of the day, everyone knows that the moneys that have been ripped off those workers is their deferred earnings which have been held in trust for them by the employer. They are entitlements which they have already earned. Although they have been held in trust by the employer, what has occurred in these circumstances is nothing more than outright thievery of the deferred wages which those employees worked hard to achieve.

I support the bill because it is an attempt to address some of these issues in trying to ensure, at a minimum, that there is some degree of protection for workers in circumstances where companies are either about to go insolvent or where there are deliberate strategies put in place in order to create the circumstances where workers' entitlements are excluded in an insolvency situation.

I take this opportunity to inform the chamber that when Senator Kemp referred to me being secretary of the metal trades union, again he misled the chamber because no such organisation exists and never has existed in the history of unionism in this country. It is not unusual for Senator Kemp to come into this chamber and consistently get it wrong in answering questions about any issue that is put before him.

My own organisation, the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union, of which I was proud to be the national secretary for some years, has already embarked upon a scheme that is in line with the proposal in this bill but goes much further. It is much more radical in the approach they want to take. Their proposal is to establish an industry trust fund that provides protection and portability of provisions, as well as security. They propose to have a fund that will have employees' entitlements set aside into it as they accrue. As workers earn those entitlements, those entitlements will be put somewhere where they cannot be ripped of by employers. They will be put in a secure fund which will provide those entitlements for them. It is proposed to be an industry-wide fund in the manufacturing sector and it will involve a number of unions in its process.

It is proposed to work, for example, with annual leave in awards which accrue on a weekly basis of 2.53 hours per week. The employer would be required to pay that amount into the trust fund on a weekly or monthly basisâmuch the same as superannuation is currently administered. The employee would hold an account with the fund that contains all of the entitlements that that employee accrues, whether they are short or long term, such as long service leave, annual leave, retrenchment pay and so forth. If a company is placed in liquidation for any reason, then the employees' entitlements would be drawn from the fund and not be dependent on the employer.

Part of the current problem is that businesses believe that they are entitled to a long-term interest free loan and can use this money for business. They cannot; it is the workers' money that workers have already earned. When a company or business collapses they have not set these earnings aside and the workers lose if the company is liquidated. It is simply unfair to make the worker bear the risk of company failureâeach business in Australia must bear the risk of company failure. Each business in Australia must bear that risk and must contribute to avoiding making it the workers' problem.

The AMWU fund goes a step further than the bill, where it will provide for a number of different scenarios, many of which are of great benefit to employers, including the fact that upon transmission of business the employee entitlements will remain with the fund so that new employers are not lumped with the burden of immediately paying out annual leave, long service leave or accrued entitlements.

As workers become more transientâwe have already seen casualisation of our work force in this country grow from 13 per cent in the manufacturing sector in 1983 to 26 or 27 per cent at this timeâthose entitlements that workers have will be secure and the people who are put on as part-time or casual employees will not be disadvantaged in terms of their overall entitlements compared to those who are lucky enough to be in secure and permanent employment.

This type of scheme, in fact, is not new; it has been working in some other forms within the building and construction industry for a considerable time. My colleague Senator Forshaw would be familiar with some of the schemes that have been operating in that area, such as CERT and MERT, where the benefits of the interest that has accrued on those moneys are ploughed back into the industry in training and other benefits for the work force in those industries. So additional benefits are gained out of the establishment of the fund and the holding of those workers' moneys in trust on their behalf.

The provisions of this bill are already in place in many jurisdictions abroad. Every country in the European Union, for example, has a wage guarantee institution in place. So it is not difficult or impossible to put together a package, which we say this bill at a minimum addresses, that can provide every worker in this country with security over the entitlements they have accrued while they have been in the work force. It can be done with a single company, an individual company, or it can be done by employment in an industry collectively or through a range of employers. That position can be achieved and can be achieved without any significant difficulty. I do not think it is adequate or appropriate for Senator Tierney to come in here on behalf of the government and say, `It is all too difficult. It is unconstitutional. It is not workable. So therefore we should not worry too much about it.' If this government had the remotest concern about the interests of battlers, they would be joining with the Australian Labor Party in ensuring that the bill does have all of the constituent parts to enable it to get through both houses of parliament and be speedily passed into law.

But I suggest that people on the other side of the chamber are not serious about doing anything in this area to protect the entitlements of workers. They never have been interested in protecting workers' rights. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has made that clear publicly. He has publicly said that he is there to work on behalf of the people who control capital in this country. He has made public statements to that effect. He has not hidden his bias in terms of what drives his agenda on behalf of this government. I think it is important for us to try to provide a mechanism to ensure that workers' hard-earned entitlements are not able to be ripped off by shonky company arrangements and setting up hollow logs within companies.

I finish on one point that was made by Senator Tierney with respect to the waterfront. He talked about the savings and the achievements that occurred on the waterfront through the reform package put in place by this government and Patrick Stevedores. I suggest that Senator Tierney should go and talk to some of the end users on the waterfront and ask them what they have achieved under waterfront reform, because they will tell him that none of the savings have been passed on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe bill that we are debating this afternoon is for an act to amend the Workplace Relations Act and the Corporations Law. This bill, the Employment Security Bill, seeks to protect the entitlements of employees affected by company insolvencies. This is the second time that the opposition has introduced this legislation into the parliament. I recall that the bill was first introduced into the Senate by Senator Mackay at about this time last year, and it is similar to a bill that was introduced last year and again this year by the member for Prospect, Janice Crosio. On that occasion, the bill was wearing the title of the Employee Protection (Wage Guarantee) Bill.

speech.para: This time the bill does, however, insert a new section 170JI to allow the Industrial Relations Commission or the Federal Court to order reinstatement upon an employer deemed a related body corporate. There is also a new section 178A which has the effect of ensuring that a related body corporate can be held liable for the payment of legal entitlements of employees. Amendments to the Corporations Law deal with the liability of a related body corporate for debts of a company being wound up in insolvency.

What the speakers this afternoon have told us is that the bill will give employees a measure of job security. Senator Mackay, in fact, in her second reading speech a year ago, said that job security is a `vital and fundamental issue for all Australians' and that job security is `fundamental to all aspects of family life' and `a matter of concern to the entire community'. Of course, we on this side of the chamber would agree wholeheartedly.

Protection for employee entitlements is, however, already being considered by the Labour Ministers Council, which is also considering amendments to the Corporations Law. In fact, the Ministerial Council on Corporations just last month agreed in principle to two of our proposals: firstly, a penalty against misuse of company structures to avoid payment of employee entitlements; and, secondly, strengthening related party and insolvent trading provisions to cover uncommercial transactions. These proposals will be discussed again at the council's next meeting but, of course, details of these in-principle agreements have already been released publicly by Senator Campbell's colleague the New South Wales Attorney-General, Mr Jeff Shaw.

Our Treasury has asked whether the Corporations Law changes that have been proposed in this bill are workable. That issue has not been covered in the speeches so far. But under certain sections of the Corporations Law, the Industrial Relations Commission is already empowered to have corporations who are suspected of breaching the civil penalty provisions to pay compensation. Surely this means that sections of this bill are duplicated and will add confusion to this existing area of law. The Corporations Law already extensively covers provisions for the recovery and the return of money to insolvent companies for the benefit of all creditors and not just employees.

talk.start.para: âDirectors can be liable.
