âIndeed, Senator O'Chee; directors can be liable. When the bill was last debated in this chamber, the opposition was warned that the bill had a number of difficulties. One of these concerns was with the constitutional validity of the bill, which appeared very doubtful in regard to its proposed amendments to the Workplace Relations Act. Again, where is the evidence that this time the homework has been done to make sure that the bill is constitutional this time around? Of particular interest would be whether both the purported acquisition of property and the impermissible conferral of non-judicial power on a federal court would survive a constitutional challenge in the High Court.

speech.para: I was fascinated by some of Senator George Campbell's contribution today, particularly in relation to his comments on the agenda regarding Patrick's. Just have a look at the performance on the waterfront now. I would direct some of those opposite to go down to the waterfront in Melbourne, where they will find on many days of the week that the Melbourne docks are achieving world's best practice. And are those waterfront workers proud of it! There are no more rorts on the Melbourne waterfront, and the Melbourne waterfront workers are very proud of it.

Of Sydney, I would ask the question: how many waterfront workers in Sydney no longer belong to the MUA? How many of them are making more money than they made before? And how many of them are going home to their families very proud of their work efforts and pay packet that they take home to share with their families? Surprise, surprise! When all this happened, the sky did not fall in. It did not fall in over the Melbourne waterfront when they achieved world's best practice, and it is not falling in over the Sydney waterfront when there are non-MUA workers working alongside MUA colleagues on the waterfront.

I will never forget the visit that I had from a delegation of waterfront workers during the heady days of the dispute. They were what I call a `Henny-Penny' delegation: they come in wringing their hands, looking at the floor and shuffling their feet, and they have a wad of papers. They are there to tell you that the sky is going to fall in if a particular piece of legislation is passed.

On this occasion it was an MUA delegation, and it was just after the wonderful 60 Minutes piece on the MUA boss John Coombs, strolling among his Chardonnay grapes down there on the Southern Highlands, riding on his tractor and on his horse, galloping around like a farmer. I posed a question to them that they could not answer at the time, and I never heard John Coombs answer it either. The question was: if a wharfie can be a farmer, why can't a farmer be a wharfie? And the answer was, `Because he is not a member of the MUA.'

It was an interesting delegation, and they spent a good hour with me. They did invite me down to the Melbourne waterfront. Unfortunately, I have not been able to accept that opportunity, but it would be a very proud moment to be down there when the Melbourne waterfront achieves world's best practice. As far as I understand, you can go on any day because you are pretty likely to find, on three or four days of the week, that that record has been achieved. I have no doubt that those waterfront workers who formed that delegation would feel as proud as the rest of Australia does to see that happening.

I got out a public relations kit that they left behind that day. I kept it because I thought at the time that whoever the agency was that had put it together would probably not be somebody that ought to be chosen again to put together a public relations kit, because on the front of this kit marked `The Docks' was half a truck, half a ship and a bunch of twisted old wharf piles. I could not help thinking that, if these people were coming to my office to tell me that our legislation and our actions were going to decimate the docks, they would have wanted to put a slightly more positive twist on the cover of their public relations document that they left behindâbut there you are. It is in my files, gathering a bit of dustâone of the more unfortunate faces of the waterfront that I think the MUA thought they were selling at the time.

Senator George Campbell also referred to workers at the Grafton abattoir who, he said, were owed more than $3 million. This was part of the argument for the opposition's bill. There are some additional pieces of informat ion that I think the chamber should know about in relation to this matter. Last year, the local member, Ian Causley, and Senator Bill O'Chee succeeded in forcing a related company to contribute $3.25 million to pay unsecured creditors, using existing provisions of the insolvency regime contained in the Corporations Law.

I am sorry that Senator George Campbell is not here to hear this piece of information because I think it is a very important piece of information. It is very important to note that more money was owed to ordinary unsecured creditors, and Senator O'Chee and the local member, Mr Ian Causley, ensured that all creditors were better off overall. This was agreed to by creditors in October 1998. Senator George Campbell completely and curiously overlooked what two coalition members were able to achieve at that time. It did get a significant amount of publicity at the time. I am surprised that his research for his speech today did not enable him to comment on that. In fact, Senator George Campbell talked about job losses and it triggered in my mind an interesting fragment of history whichâ
Senator O'Chee interjectingâ
Senator Forshaw interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder, Senator O'Chee and Senator Forshaw! You two will have your chance to participate in the debate later. Senator Ferris is entitled to be heard.

âI appreciate your support, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I was explaining to the chamber, in the dark corners of my mind I recalled a comment made by former Prime Minister Keating about Senator George Campbell and job losses. I went searching for it and I found that it was former Prime Minister Keating who said that Senator George Campbell, in his previous life, carried around his neck the jobs of 100,000 workers. I am glad to hear that Senator George Campbell is now agreeing in this place that job security is very important and that, like us, he is working towards a set of circumstances that will achieve that.

speech.para: Let us never forget that it was the current Leader of the Opposition who, as minister for employment in the previous Keating government, was responsible for the highest rate of unemployment since the Depressionâthe highest rate of unemployment in 60 years. What a badge of honour that is for the Leader of the Opposition! In fact, unemployment under the Labor government reached 11.3 per cent and resulted in more than one million unemployed in early 1993ânot a lot of job security there for workers and their families. Many of them lost their jobs and were without jobs for many years. Unemployment was a chronic problem at the start of the decade and Labor did very little to protect the security of employees then. Labor had an opportunity over 13 years to fix this piece of legislation to give this security to employees. They also had the opportunity to fix the taxation system, which would do as much or more to help job security as this bill that Senator Collins has brought in today.

The Labor Party is big on rhetoric but it often never delivers when it comes to employment security. When Labor came to government in 1983, there were surveys that showed that job security rates were at 79 per cent. By 1992, that figure had declined to just above 60 per cent and by last year the figure was back to 77 per cent. It is fascinating to note that in Labor's last year of office it was actually union members themselves who were most likely to feel insecure about their job prospects. How could it be that people in the union work force felt so insecure about their jobs? To me, it is a terrible reflection on the members and leaders of the trade unions who sit in this place.

Over the past year, 180,000 new jobs have been created in Australia. That totals 400,000 jobs since the election of the Howard government in 1996. Unemployment is at its lowest level for a decade. In fact, the number of unemployed young peopleâI know that Senator George Campbell and all members of the Labor Party will also regard this as a very high priorityâhas now declined by over 20 per cent since the 1996 election. It is now at the lowest level since records began being kept on this part of the employment market in 1978. What greater gift is there to a young person than a job and job security? There is no higher priority in Australia than to get our young people off the couch, out of the house and actually working and making a contribution to this country.

Home loan interest rates are also at their lowest level since 1970. This represents a saving on a typical loan for a family of $4,000 a year on interest rate payments compared with March of 1996. Small business borrowing rates and inflation are at their lowest levels since the 1960s. All of these things contribute to job security. It is not just about legislation; it is about a growing economy. Economic growth this year has been at a rate of 4.25 per cent, far higher than any of the other leading economies of the world or in fact the OECD averages. This week's budget predicts economic growth of three per cent. That is where the jobs will come. That is where there is employment security. The best insurance for job security is a healthy growing, expanding economy.

Senator Collins wants to protect employees and their wages. So does this government. The best way to do that is to have a healthy and growing economy. The right economic fundamentalsâthat is, economic growth and tax reformâare the best way to ensure employment security. That is why this government wants to reform the taxation system. In evidence from Professor Dixon to the Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Committee, it was demonstrated that under the government's proposed tax reforms employment will be stimulated in the short run by about 30,000 jobs. How is that for job security? How is that for long-term job security? That is another 30,000 jobs. When we come in here to debate today a bill which will legislate for job security, why do we not consider passing the tax reform bills, because independent arms-length advice shows that 30,000 jobs will be stimulated and created in the short run by the passing of our tax legislation?

Access Economics, in their December 1998 model forecast, report that in the long run the impact of the tax package raises an additional 190,000 jobs. What we have here is evidence that at the minimum we are talking about 30,000 jobs and at the maximum we could be talking about 190,000 jobs. They are jobs for our young people, the unemployed, families, women and indigenous communities. There will be job security and, at the end of the day, a sense that these groups will have contributed to this country. They will have a sense of satisfaction that comes from making a contribution.

Taxation reform will return to Australian employees the incentive to work by placing 81 per cent of Australian taxpayers on a maximum tax rate of 30 per cent or less. Again, what better job security is there? There will be more jobs, and small business will prosper. Why will the opposition not pass that legislation?

The new tax system will remove impediments on businesses so that Australian industries can compete efficiently on international markets. By making exports GST free, we will have enterprises that will be outward focused and concentrated on stimulating the domestic economy, where the jobs are and where the job security is. That will have an impact not just in this bill but out in the workplace, including in our small businesses, and out in our economy.

More workplace relations reform will also deliver jobs. However, we know what sort of shiver goes down the spine of those opposite when that subject is raised. Their telephones ring hot from the Henny Penny delegations, who cry, `We can't have that! We can't have any more of those!' They are the sacred cows of the Labor Party's economy, and they are the people who do not deliver the job security.

Further simplifying the award system will encourage further agreement making and organisational effectiveness, which will further encourage employment growth. Secret ballots will be put in place. They are the incentives we need to place in this economy to get it growing and working. That is where the job security is and where the new jobs will come from for our young people and women. The jobs will be for those people who want to work part-time and full-time, for those who want to strike their own agree ments with their employers and for those who will provide the job security for the rest of the Australian economy.

Senator Campbell said that job security is a vital and fundamental issue for all Australians and so is the security of workers' earnings. There is absolutely no doubt that we agree. Economic growth is the best way to ensure employment stability. That is why we want to reform the taxation system and the industrial relations system. That is why the budget delivered this week builds on Australia's impressive job record. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI will start my remarks by picking up on those of Senator Ferris. In her conclusion just a moment ago, she talked about economic growth. This country has enjoyed unprecedented economic growth for a number of years now. There were certainly significant levels of economic growth in the latter years of the Keating government. We have seen economic growth running at between three and four per cent or more in the last few years. Much of that is due to the fundamental changes that were brought to the Australian economy throughout the Hawke and Keating years. For the first time, this country and the government realised that we lived in an international economy and that we had to reshape the economy of this country if we were going to cut it with the rest of the world. Whilst I, as a proud trade union official, throughout those years did not necessarily like some of the necessary decisions that the Labor government made, I now recognise that much of the prosperity and economic growth we enjoy today is due to the foundations laid down in those years.

speech.para: Senator Ferris says that we need economic growth in this country to create job security. We have had economic growth for quite a number of years now, but there is very little economic security for a lot of workers in this country. We even saw today in question time Senator Alston acknowledge that, with the latest employment figures, we have seen a drop in full-time employment and an increase in part-time employment. That is one of the problems with the policies that the govern ment is promoting; that is, there is less and less emphasis on secure full-time employment.

The government only has to look at the proposal it keeps putting up that we need to weaken the unfair dismissal laws. We have this strange argument that says that if you can make it easier to sack workers you will end up employing more workers. That statement only has to be put forward to be refuted. It is a nonsense. If you look at the statistics, you will find that throughout the years of the Labor government when the unfair dismissal laws were passed and strengthened at the federal level, particularly because of some of the actions of state premiers such as Jeff Kennett, there was actually growth in employment in small business. Yet this government continues to argue that all will be solved because all you have to do is make it easier to sack workers.

I am not going to get too distracted by replying to the many erroneous arguments that Senator Ferris put forward, because I do want to return to what this debate is really about. This debate is about the need for job securityâfor protecting the legal entitlements of workers in this country. That is the issue that we are debating here this afternoon.
Senator Ferris interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt is indicative that Senator Ferris and her colleagues have very little to say about this issue other than that they support it in principle but it is all too hard. It is indicative of the paucity of their arguments when they have to spend the last five or 10 minutes of their allotted 20 minutes talking about the GST and economic growth when we are dealing with a specific proposal to bring in legislation at the federal level to ensure that workers' legal entitlements are protected.

speech.para: I am not surprised that you were not able to speak on that issue for the entire period. Like Senator Tierney and some of your colleagues, you have said that you support it in principle. How could you say anything else? But you have not got any constructive proposals to put forward. All you can do is stand up and say, `Well, there's been a meeting of labour ministers, and they are working on some proposals. Down the track, maybe, we might get around to some sort of an agreement sometime about doing this nationally.' What we are talking about is specific federal legislation to address these issues. You have also saidâand this argument has been put forward by others from the governmentâthat this proposal could well be unconstitutional. I do not think it is, but evenâ

talk.start.para: âYou're a High Court judge as well!

âNo, I am not a High Court judge but, without blowing my own trumpet, I do have some degree of experience in industrial law, having spent 18 years appearing before the Industrial Relations Commission. The fact of the matter is that, if there is a constitutional issue but you agree with this proposal in principle, why don't you work with us? Why don't you come forward with some legislative proposals to address it? Why don't you do that?
âYou won't work with us on the tax bills.

âWe do not agree with your tax billsâthat is why we will not work with you on them. We oppose them; we know they will hurt workers. You say you agree with us in principle that workers' rights and workers' entitlements should be protected. Put your money where your mouth is and come up with some concrete proposals, rather than standing there attacking the opposition and claiming, `Oh, well. It may be unconstitutional. It may offend the Corporations Law, and there are all these problems, such as how do you extract debts from related companies when other companies go bankrupt, and so on?'

speech.para: I want to get onto the specific issue that is before us, because it does clearly demonstrate the difference between us and the government. We stand for protection of workers and their legal entitlements. When I say that, I want to stress that it is not just about workers and their entitlements, it is about workers' families and their entitlements. When employees are dismissed with very little noticeâas has happened in many cases, such as the Grafton meatworks, and I will come back to thatâtheir families suffer as well.

At the Grafton meatworks in December 1998, just a couple of weeks before Christmas, workers were suddenly told that the meatworks were closing down, that they were out of a job and that there was not any money to pay them their accrued annual leave and other entitlements. They had to go home to their familiesâtwo weeks before Christmasâand say, `I'm sorry. I've just lost my job.' I will come back to that issue in a moment and deal with some of the facts, as distinct from the claims of Senator Ferris that it was Mr Causley and Senator O'Chee who rescued the workers on that occasion. That is not true.

Since 1996, when this government came to power, we have seen a government that does not put job security and security of workers' entitlements to the foreârather, it relegates them to the dustbin. Let us look at the record of this government, in terms of its industrial relations legislation, since it came to office. One of the first things it did was set out to emasculate the Industrial Relations Act, and it did so. It legislated to remove a whole range of provisions from industrial awards by a set date if the parties had not agreed to negotiate the removal of those provisions. It legislated to make it more difficult for workers and legal, free, democratic, registered trade unions to represent their members before the Industrial Relations Commission. It sought to legislate to make it easier to dismiss people. We have seen Mr Reith in recent times say that there is more to come. He has a few more ideas about how he can reduce the powers of the Industrial Relations Commission and, more and more, drive workersâparticularly low paid workersâinto a system where they do not have equal bargaining power with employers.

If you are not prepared, because of your ideology, to accept that workers and corporations or other employers do not have equal bargaining power in most situations, then you only have to look at the issue that we are discussing here. Who is it who suffers when businesses such as Cobar mine, Woodlawn mineâand these are not small businessesâand Grafton meatworks close? Who is it who suffers? It is the workers. The directors do not suffer, as in the case of Grafton meatworks. The Gilbertsons did not suffer. They have a whole range of other corporate interests in industry and land development to keep them fed, housed, clothed, in employment and picking up directors' fees. But the workers did not have that.

When you can work for a company for years and years and then be sacked with hardly any notice, and you cannot even get the money you are owed for your annual leave, your other entitlements and your superannuation, how can that possibly be equal bargaining? It is a nonsense for Mr Reith and others to suggest that, in this new world of workplace reform, workers in those situations can ever be equal when it comes to bargaining.

This, of course, is the government that believes that you should use the Corporations Law more and more rather than section 51(xxxv) to regulate industrial relations and conciliation and arbitration in this country. This is the government, when it was in opposition, that opposed just about every national wage increase for the lowest paid workers and opposed superannuation being extended to workers. This is the government that supported the wholesale sacking of an entire work force on the waterfront, aided and abetted by their colleagues in the National Farmers Federation.
Senator Quirke interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âExactly. This is the government that stood by and allowed subterfuge and corporate trickery to lead to the mass sacking of workers and to their entitlements being placed in jeopardy. Of course, that is what happened at Grafton meatworks. The workers there were employed by one company but all the plant and the stock were owned by another. When the bank foreclosed, the company that employed the workers had no money, just as happened on the waterfront. And what happened in Grafton?
âWhy didn't you fix it?

âWe have fixed that as far as possible. Through the efforts of Harry Woods, the state member for Clarence and the Minister for Regional Development in New South Wales, those meatworks were reopenedâand Senator Crane knows thisâand many of those workers have been rehired.
âGive yourself some credibilityâwhat about O'Chee and Causley?

âSenator O'Chee and Mr Causley have claimed a lot of credit because they wrote a few letters to the appropriate authorities with respect to seeking some money to be paid to the creditors. I am advised that all of the workers who were employed there are still owed substantial amounts of money. They have not been fully paid.
âNobody said that.

âSenator Crane, the fact of the matter is that it was the New South Wales Labor government and Harry Woods that entered into negotiations with the new owner to make it easier for him, because of the problems that were associated with some of the back charges, et cetera, that were owed, to get those meatworks reopened and get those jobs back. That was the priority and that has been achieved.

speech.para: We are now seeking to get some legislation through this parliament to fix the second problem. It is no use saying, `The Labor government had 13 years to fix this.' I concede that more may have been able to have been done in the past, but let us remember a couple of things. Firstly, the previous government did address the issues of priority in terms of employees having access to funds that might be available in liquidated companies in preference to other creditors. Secondly, what we have seen since this government came to power is a rash of these closuresâCobar mines, Woodlawn mine, Grafton meatworks and others. A whole range of them have collapsed. There has been a plethora of them. That is the immediacy of the issue, and that is why it has to be addressed now. It is no excuse to sit on your hands and say, `For 99 years we've had a legal system in this country.' The time has arrived where it has to be changed now, and we are asking you to get on board. If you believe in the principle of protecting workers' entitlements, then you will move with us to fix it.

Senator Ferris referred to the fact that this legislation was brought forward some time ago by the member for Prospect, Mrs Crosio, in the other place, and it was brought into this chamber earlier by Senator Mackay. That is right, but what have the government done since then? They have done nothing. They are just walking away from the problem rather than addressing it. But I am not surprised by that because, day in and day out in this chamber, the real picture, the real message and the real views of this government are expressed by, in particular, Senator Alston. They mention trade unions, and they think that trade unions are evil incarnate and that they are terrible organisations. They say that the Labor Party is linked with the trade union movement and therefore we are all bad.

I am very proud of having been a trade union official. I am proud of the fact that in 1988 I went to the United States and I had an opportunity to talk to the US farm workers. I went there to meet one of the greatest trade union leaders and one of the greatest citizens of America this century, Caesar Chavezâa man who led the fight to protect the rights of poor workers in the fruit industry and in other farming industries in California. Caesar Chavez was shot at and jailed for his beliefs.

I am proud of the fact that, when I went to Poland a couple of years ago, I met officials of Solidarity, a trade union led by Lech Walesa which took on the communist regime in Poland. Through their efforts, they started the wave that led to liberation for eastern Europe. Trade unions, whether you like them or not, are an integral part of a democratic society.

talk.start.para: âDon't look at me, I'm not arguing with you.

âI have said this before and I will say it again: whenever dictators get into power, the two groups that they will always challenge and seek to remove the influence of are the churches and the trade unions, because they protect the rights and entitlements of workers and of ordinary people.

speech.para: Senator Crane, I know you better than a lot of other members because we have dealt with some of these issues in the past. I know that you actually think trade unions are decent organisations. Why don't you encourage some of your colleagues to stop this stereotyping and attacking of trade unions and to deal with some of the real issues that trade unions are proud to go out there and protectâthe entitlements of workers and their families?

I challenge you to get on board with us and fix a problem that needs fixing, so that ordinary working men and women in this country can know that, when they go to work and they earn their entitlements, they will be protected and that, eventually, when they happen to retire or if they unfortunately happen to lose their job, they will be paid their just and due entitlements. That is what should occur in a free and just society such as ours. It is about time the government took up that challenge and fixed this problem.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to have an opportunity to speak this afternoon on this general business motion. This bill reminds me of that marvellous film Groundhog Day , in which the main character kept waking up morning after morning to relive what had happened the day before. This went on ad nauseam.
âIt's a new parliament now.
âThe reason I am reminded of this is that we debated this bill approximately a year ago in this chamber. It had been introduced by different ALP sponsors in the previous parliament.
âDon't you know how legislation works?
âNow it crops up again, in almost identical terms, sponsored by Mr Arch Bevis, the shadow minister for industrial relations in the other place, and by Senator Collins in this chamber.
âI thought you were a barrister.

âIt had a previous incarnation when it was introducedâwith a few differencesâby Mrs Crosio as a private member's bill, seeking a slightly different scheme. She was seeking a compulsory wage protection scheme.

speech.para: Another Groundhog Day feature of the bill, for me at least, is that Labor appears to have learnt nothing, despite having looked at this bill so many times. That is the really extraordinary thing about this. That is why, Senator Collins, I am talking about the fact that you have had so many chances to get it right and you have still got it wrong. You have got it wrong technically. Leaving aside the policy position for a minute, you simply do not understand how insolvency law works; nor do you understand how the constitutional arrangements of this country work. You certainly have not learnt anything from the previous outings this bill has had.

In my speech during the second reading debate on the 1998 bill on 25 June last year, I pointed outâI thought it was in some painstaking detailâthat the provisions in the bill, as they stood, were likely to be held to be constitutionally invalid. I did this free of charge and I did it in a bipartisan way. I will refer back to what I said, because Senator Forshaw went to some pains to invite us to be bipartisan about this. What I said on that occasion last year is being totally ignored; maybe it will not be this time. I said:

The issue of ensuring entitlements of employees in a case where an employer has engaged in corporate restructuring is, in fact, a very complex one. I can say, as an entirely personal matter, that those who have tried to wrestle with this bill have my personal sympathy because it is a very complex issue to address, and any solution must not be based on a knee-jerk response to a particular factual situation. I think that is really what we have here.
I went on to say that it had been a predictable response to some recent events by those who sit opposite. I will come to that a little later. I also said:

. . . the Corporations Law already contains provisions that allow a liquidator to undo preferential transactions involving related parties in the period leading to the winding-up of a company. Therefore, if a company is proven to be engaged in sham transactions in order to wrongfully terminate the employment of its work force, appropriate remedies already exist.

I might say, in a gesture of a true bipartisan approach to this, that it is worth looking at whether or not you have already got the remedies. I certainly do restate, on behalf of the government, a commitment to finding a solutionâ
which the government is doingâ
to the issue of protecting the entitlement of employees on employer insolvency, but I do caution against any haste or overreaching in respect of this matter.
I thought that that was a perfectly appropriate way to approach this debate. It is very disappointing, for two reasons, that you do not seem to be able to grasp it.

talk.start.para: âWe understand. You are talking about remedies after legal action.

âI will try it again, Senator Forshaw. Let us see if you can do a bit better this time. Firstly, an attempt to make a related body corporate liable for the payment of legal entitlements of employees of an insolvent company is perilously close to a compulsory acquisition of property. You know as well as everyone else in this chamber that, if it is that, it is constitutionally invalid.

speech.para: The second point about it is that the attempt to give the Australian Industrial Relations Commission or the Federal Court power to deem a related company to be the relevant employer for an order for reinstatement is also an impermissible conferral of non-judicial power on a federal court. I would have thought those two propositions were not too difficult to grasp and that, if you were really serious about what you are proposing to do in this bill, you would have made a much more serious attempt to deal with those issues than simply trotting out the old rhetoric and an identical bill. I am very surprised that there appears to have been very little attempt to actually grasp the problem you have got. It is your problem, if you want this bill, to actually make it workable. It is just astounding that you should trot out a defective bill. Anyway, that is obviously your problem.

The way you have approached the attempt to amend section 1317HD of the Corporations Law in respect of insolvent trading and payment of liabilities is also a puzzle. This is because you have copied it blindly from the 1998 bill. I can understand that you might have missed the point, but apparently this is in total ignorance of the amendments made to the section by the passage of the Managed Investments Bill last year. This is pretty easy to grasp. Labor's position on this is really very curious. Firstly, the proposal substantially duplicates a recommendation of the 1988 report of the general insolvency inquiry, which was the Harmer report. Surprisingly, despite the passion on the other side, that was not adopted into law by the Labor government when it had a chance. When Senator Collins's party was in power, they had open slather. You had a chance to do what you are seeking to do now, and you simply did not do it. That is why this effort totally lacks credibility. You copied the amendments from last year's Employment Security Bill, and they failed to take into account the amendments to the Managed Investments Act which came into effect on 1 July last year. So we have got the same outdated and obsolete clause coming back again.

I can only conclude from this chain of events that you cannot be serious about working towards a workable national scheme to protect entitlements, which is sometimes necessary when an employer becomes bankrupt. If you did, you would be doing something in a more constructive manner. This feeble attempt by the Labor Party is not a genuine attempt to address this at all. It is pretty easy to see that Labor has got its marching orders from Trades Hall, as usual, and this is the result. For the Labor Party to actually come in here after its appalling performance on jobs and employment security and then advocate a defective bill, a bill that it knows must be defective, means that it could only come from the trade union movement. It is all because of the Patrick case. Senator Cook said that in the case of Patrick's it was designed to give to employees of the Patrick companies, not just to receivers, the right to sue Chris Corrigan and other Patrick directors for debts arising from breaches of the Corporations Law. So we know what this is all about. We know the minority group that it is trying to assist.

It did not help when the employees of the Brown and Hatton piggery had similar problems. Labor was in government then, and the solution that you now advocate was available to you then, but nothing was done about it. This is not only breathtaking; it is also nonsensical. If you are interested in this reform, if you are seriously interested in trying to address this problem, you do something constructive about it, and this bill certainly is not a genuine attempt.

Labor have shown that they are not interested in the costs on business and the adverse impact on employment, particularly in relation to small to medium business, of any scheme that is put up to assist with security of employment. They are not interested in job security of ordinary Australian workers; they are only interested in those workers who are members of a union. It is very interesting that the membership application form to join the Victorian branch of the Labor Party, which I have with meâI am not going to fill it out; let us not get worried about thatârequires those who fill out the form and wish to join the ALP to pledge that if they employ labourâ

talk.start.para: âWhat has this got to do with the bill?

âI know they are upset, Mr Acting Deputy President, but this is why it is relevant. It says: `If I employ labour, I will only employ trade union members.' Isn't that the most extraordinary indictment of a political party that professes to have some interest in job security? It is only interested in employing people who are members of a union. That is extraordinary. It is only interested in those workers who are members of a union. What really hurts is that they are shrinking in number. The only place that union membership is increasing is in the Senate. Union membership is a shrinking number. Recent figures indicate a decline in union membership to 28 per cent. The percentage of workers that you want to protect who are in a union has declined to a mere 28 per cent, which includes both the public and private sectors.

speech.para: So Labor are interested, according to this application form, in giving priority to giving jobs to and protecting 28 per cent of the working population, an elite minority group. They ignore and prejudice the job security of the other 72 per cent of workers in this country. There cannot be any doubt that Australia's sound economic position has been underpinned by the industrial relations reforms that this country has seen since the coalition came to government. But, still dancing to the tune of their union mates, the ALP has systematically opposed workplace relations reforms that will really give workers job security and that will give all Australians better job prospects and better job security.

Mr Bevisâwho has carriage of this bill, or this attempt at a bill, in the other placeâhas certainly had some interesting things to say about further necessary industrial relations reforms proposed by the minister, Mr Reith. In an address to the Australian Industry Group on 5 March this year, as spokesman for industrial relations, he indicated that a future Labor government would in fact wind back the clock on industrial relations, that Labor would continue to oppose the coalition on any industrial relations reforms and that a future Labor government would swing the pendulum further back to the left than ever before. Mr Bevis also committed the ALP to the union movement. He said he was opposed to any moves to have the trade unions sidelined and argued that there would always be a case for regulation, for laws that confer rights on unions. He even favoured a return to a fully unionised work force.

Given that in that speech he commits Labor to reversing all the freedom of association provisions achieved under the coalition and that he appears to favour legislative rights for unions, it is an interesting question whether a Labor government would attempt once more to make unionism compulsory. If it does, you can say goodbye to any jobs growth in this country and to the protection of any workers in this country.

Mr Bevis seems to believe, according to his speech, that higher wages `increase employment levels'. I do not really understand how he puts that. But when he outlines the foundations for an effective coordinated policy, he wishes to include a progressive tax and well targeted industry support schemes. He does not say how they would work, but that is a very interesting point because it appears, in relation to Mrs Crosio's version of the bill that we are currently examining, that Mr Beazley was given a warning about the downside of imposing levies on the cost of jobs.

This is extremely interesting because the proposal was to introduce legislation enacted to levy employers for employee guarantee funds. The private briefing note to Mr Beazley that I am reading from says:
This basically is what Janice's bill proposesâ
Janice is Mrs Crosioâ
It is also in line with what the ACTU wants.

Isn't that an interesting coincidence? Here we have a proposal from a Labor member and a private member's bill and a briefing to Mr Beazley, the leader of the Labor Party, who is told whether or not it is actually in line with what the ACTU wants. That is because it is necessary for Labor always to look at what the unions want. The Labor Party is completely run by them. Unions are the ghost of the Labor Party.
An adviser to Mr Beazley, Mr John Angley, said that there was a reservation about the approach of this particular legislation or bill. He said:

The downside of a levy is that it is another cost on jobs. If it is a statewide fund, like workers compensation, the cost per worker in the form of premiums inevitably grows. It also reduces the responsibility of employers and their owners to fix their own affairs rather than fall back on the fund.
So there we have an admission on behalf of those opposite that a levy is in fact a cost on jobs and that the provisions within this bill will cost jobs if it is ever enacted.

Mr Bevis has said that the alternative direction which Labor is pursuing is in their 10-point plan to undo all of the Reith reforms that have taken place since the coalition came to government. It is very interesting that, although Senator George Campbell seems to find some support for that proposition, others in the Labor Party seem to think very differently. I will quote from Mr Mark Latham's Civilising Global Capital at page 85, where he says:

Whereas in its origins unionism was a force for economic change and progress, it has now fallen into the habit of opposing change in its contribution to most issues. In Australia there is little evidence to suggest that the leadership of the union movement has adapted successfully to the demands of the new economy.

I can add that sadly the Labor Party are also in that boat. You have simply failed to adapt to the demands of the new economy. All you can do is oppose propositions. You can never support a constructive proposal. Mr Latham goes on to say, and this is a fitting point for me to conclude on:

The danger for the relevance of political Labor lies in the way in which this narrow base of unionism might foster a concentration of employment strategies on capital intensive manufacturing industries at the expense of the growth potential of the services sector.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis is not a bill about trade unionism; it is rather a bill about the corporate sector. Mr Acting Deputy President, you have had much to do with the corporate sector and most people in the corporate sector act honourably and try to go about doing their work as they should. The corporate sector gives a lot of life to the economy that we all hope to enjoy.

speech.para: This bill is about those in the corporate sector who do not play the game. No doubt there are people in the work force who do not play the game. But because some people do not play the game does not mean that the group they belong to is thereby damned. This is not a bill that tries to condemn those people who carry on in corporate life as they should. But the people, the firms and the companies that have been quoted here today are not the sorts of people that ought be allowed to carry on as the proprietors of businesses.

I can give an example of what happens: you have a corporation which gathers under its auspices both the assets and the employees of that corporation so that the assets and the employees are in the same loop, if I can use that expression. Quite deliberately, these people separate those two things outâthey separate the employees from the assets by creating two separate companies. One company owns the assets, the other employs the employees.

talk.start.para: âThey are hollow logs.

âAs has been said, they are hollow logs. Senator Campbell is quite right about that. Everybody knows the concept. What has that to do with unionism, excepting this: if the unions do not do something about it then they are not doing the right thing? How can a union collect fees from its members and not try to do something about the outrageous situation that happens in places like Wodonga Meats, Patricks or the Mount Schank meatworks near Mount Gambier in South Australia? In that last situation they separated the assets and the employees by separating the employees into a company without the employees even knowing about it. A company was created and unbeknownst to the employees they were transferred to that company, which had no assets. In that situation the employees were left without proper wagesâwithout wages at all. That was done without any consent on their part. There are now provisions in the Workplace Relations Act which help a bit. Section 298K is of considerable help in that situation. But clearly it does not go far enough.

speech.para: Much criticism has been made of Senator Collins's bill. Of course you can criticise a bill; we criticise many bills in here. But when we criticise a bill we do not say, `Because it is not tidy in all respects we will throw it out.' The point of arguing about a bill in this chamber is to get a bill that accommodates the situation. I would have thought that, given the things that have happened in places like Cobar, Wodonga, Grafton and Mount Schank we would all, as a parliament, try to do something about it.

Simply because somebody wants to do something about an employee who is thrown out of work and left without the money that is due to him, and that person raises the proposition that something ought to be done about the situation, such a person should not beâin fact cannot beâdismissed simply because it is said that she has some relationship with a union. Senator Collins had a very proud relationship with a union. Likewise, Senator Campbell had many years in the union movementâ27 years. Not only would they expect the union movement to do something about the situation, they would expect the Labor Party, the coalition and the Australian community to do something about the situation because this is unfair on people who live in our society.

Mr Acting Deputy President, if a neighbour of yours or mine or Senator Herron or Senator Coonan was unjustly ripped apart and had their money taken from them by a very shallow trick when they had worked and a debt had accumulated to them, wouldn't you hope that something would be done to cure the situation? When the government talks about this bill as being some sort of union or Labor Party plot, they do a great disservice to our fellow citizens. If the government members thought about this they would move to create a situation where the sorts of instances we have talked about do not happen again and where our fellow citizens are treated properly and are able to get the wages they are entitled to.
Debate interrupted.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.00 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That the Senate take note of the Budget statement and documents.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, during the election campaign, we said this government did not have a plan for our nation; it had a plan for a tax. This budget shows we were right. Instead of investing in our future, it invests in its own obsession. And the price of its folly will be borne by the generations to come, because without the investments needed to make our nation and our future work force smarter and more productive, we will not have the high wage, high skill future the people of this nation deserve.

speech.para: The good growth recorded in this budget stems from the industry and resilience of the Australian people, and hard decisions taken by this government's predecessor over a decade ago. We enjoy prosperity today because, more than a decade ago, government saw the priority of restructuring the Australian economy to secure our nation's future.

Back then, a strong national government with an eye to the future saw the need to diversify our economy because global economic trends were promising a brighter and more prosperous future in new industries. We saw the need to broaden our industrial base from our reliance on cyclical industries, such as resources and agriculture, and get into areas like elaborately transformed manufactures to boost trade, growth and jobs.

But the game has moved on yet again. Today, global economic trends are rewarding those nations supplying high knowledge content products. The new competitive landscape is about software, pharmaceuticals, communications and information technology, biotechnology, education exports and the like. We have no choice but to engage. Our capacity to do so means the life or death of jobs in this country.

What we achieved in the past was not done with words or by an accounting result. It was achieved by government investing for the future: in education and training; in research and development; in export incentives; and in industry plans. So, too, as we look forward, our success in today's global economy demands investment in the future. Nothing short of a quantum leap in the education levels, skills and training of the Australian work force, and the national resources devoted to new industries, will see Australia join the emerging global prosperity. This, surely, should be the test we set this budget.

What we needed from the budget was a strategy for a nation making its way in the world and an understanding of the challenge before us and how together we can rise to it. This is what the times demand of national government. These are the commitments a budget must show. Firstly, there must be a commitment to fairness for future generations, which demands strong fiscal discipline. It is centred on a golden rule that governments do not borrow to finance current spending and save in the good times so that over the cycle the budget balances. It must show a commitment to making every Australian family feel more secure in terms of the income they enjoy, in terms of their jobs, in terms of educating themselves through life and in terms of their ability, if unemployed, to get back into the work force.

But it must also show a commitment to fairness as the centrepiece of our economic progress. It must show an iron determination that none of our fellow citizens is left behind as part of the bargain of our economic progress in a new century. Both of these ideasâfairness and progressâdemand the same thing. They demand a commitment to a high wage, high skill future and an opportunity for all Australians to share in that future by developing their talents to the full. Only by pulling together, by pooling our talents, will we progress with fairness to all our fellow citizens.

A good budget for these times must also demonstrate a commitment to the goal that good home-grown ideas fall on fertile soil here rather than go overseas and be lost to Australian business and Australian jobs in the future. These are the tests that Australians, in 50 or 100 years looking back, will apply to this generation.

On Tuesday night, these were the tests before this Treasurer. He was asked to answer them on television just minutes after his speech. He was asked on budget night what the vision was beyond the GST. He was asked for the vision, and what he gave us was, `Ummm'. He gave us `Ummm'. He then gave us the mouth opening and shuttingâfor once soundlessly. He gave us the mouth opening and shutting, and then he gave us multiple circular hand movements. And then he just started in again on the GST.

No performance, Madam President, could have been more eloquent. No performance could have illustrated more completely the real failure of this budget. It is not about investing for the future; it is just about a GST. How, indeed, could it be about anything else? We have now seen the cost of this GST. It is a cost which means this government can't afford anything else. It can't afford what the nation really needs.

The Treasurer announced on Tuesday surpluses of $5.4 billion, $7.2 billion, $5.2 billion and $11.4 billion over the next four years. What he didn't announce was that the attempt to sell the GST has cost the surplus $5 billion next year, $5 billion the year after that and $7 billion the year after that. That is $17 billion, and that is the real price tag of this GST.

Now leave aside for one moment whether you're a supporter or not of the GST. Leave aside the merits for and against. Ask yourself this: is it wise, is it prudent, is it strategic to spend over $17 billion to secure one public policy objective, when the nation faces so many challenges, requiring many different responses, across a range of fronts? Because that $17 billion is not just black ink.

That could be the foundation of a new nation, and still see a decent surplus maintainedâstill see all the surpluses announced on Tuesday night maintained. But it is to become just so much spun sugar around a failing tax. What should a mature nation do with such a strong budgetary positionâsquander it on measures that feed into consumption and do nothing for investmentâeconomic fairy floss? Spend more on new computers for the tax office's GST enforcement than on labour market programs for the unemployed? No, a mature nation would invest a portion of that in building the knowledge-based economy, and still leave larger surpluses than this government.
The GST is a waste of a strong budgetary position. It is a waste of a surplus built with a tax system claimed to be broken.
